My concern in all of this has been that this program has been set up with a set of guidelines that has not been adhered to from time to time in some projects that have been considered for Regional Partnerships funding. I will mention a few of those a little later in my speech. There are some new developments in the inquiry that is going on. It is appropriate at this time to bring those things to the attention of the House. As most members would be aware, I had a number of meetings with Mr Greg Maguire, a witness at the hearings, about a year ago. There has been much debate on that and I will not go back over all those issues. Mr Maguire did give certain undertakings when he was interviewed by the Senate inquiry that he would return to the inquiry certain matters of evidence that he was unable to provide on that day. I will read some of those matters into the Hansard.

The first matter I refer to relates to the Hansard of Thursday, 10 March 2005, page 27. I think it is appropriate that I read a number of exchanges between some of the senators and Mr Maguire because it leads to the integrity and truthfulness of the witness. Part of what the inquiry into Regional Partnerships and associated matters is about is the integrity of process as well as the integrity of the people involved. The Hansard reads:

quote.para: Senator CARRâMr Maguire, in your opening statement you said âMy companies have made substantial financial donationsâ to Mr Windsor. What is the extent of those substantial financial donations?
Mr MaguireâI believe they are a private matter.
Senator CARRâUnfortunately, under the laws of this country they are not private.
Mr MaguireâNo. You can find them. The Electoral Commission will have documentation onâ
Senator CARRâI have had a look at the declarations and I do not see a name on them. I am wondering how that might be.
Mr MaguireâThat is because it would be under a company name.
Senator CARRâWhich companies?
Mr MaguireâI do not think it is necessary that I sit here before you telling you that I put money into Tony Windsorâs campaign. I have said in my opening statement that I have done so.
Senator CARRâMr Maguire, the reason I have asked you this question is thatâ
Mr MaguireâYou have the statement. You have the New South Walesâ
â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦

Senator CARRâYou have raised the question. I am not trying to be difficult with you. You have raised this issue. You have stated bluntly in your evidence that you have made substantial financial donations to Mr Windsor. I cannot find them in the declarations. Any donation over $200 is required by law to be declared. Has there been an error somewhere or have you misled the committee?
Mr MaguireâI have not misled the committee. You do not have the documents there for the New South Wales government.
Senator CARRâI see. That helps me further.

Mr MaguireâLet me have a go. The documents would show that my companies have donated. I also have donated in terms of putting funds into Mr Windsorâs campaign under my companiesâ names. That could be under one of several companiesâ names and I do not believe it is necessary for me to tell you the names of those companies.
Senator CARRâAre you saying that you gave support to Mr Windsor while he was a member of the New South Wales parliament?
Mr MaguireâYes. That is correct.
Senator CARRâSo you have not done so while he is a member of the federal parliament?
Mr MaguireâHe has only been elected to the federal parliament once whilst I have been supporting him. I did not support him at the last election.

speech.para: That last sentence contradicts Mr Maguireâs recent letter back to the inquiry suggesting that he did assist in the 2004 election. So he is saying in evidence that he did not support and he is saying in evidence that he did assist. The fact is that he did not assist at all. There has never been a financial donation from Mr Maguire to any of my campaigns. I would urge the Senate inquiry to look much closer at those particular issues that have been raised.
The second area where I would like to refer to the Hansard of the Senate inquiry is on page 48 of the hearing on Thursday, 10 March:

quote.para: Senator OâBRIENâI have questions on another matter that I want to pursue. Senator Carr asked about donations to Mr Windsorâs 2001 campaign. You have effectively declined to nominate the companies that made those donations. Can you tell us whether those companies have complied with the law in declaring the donations?

speech.para: The response is very important:

quote.para: Mr MaguireâYes, they would have.

speech.para: Mr Maguire has responded to the Senate inquiry by way of letter. He has not mentioned the names of those companies. He says in evidence that he has 37 companies and that he would let the inquiry know what those companies were and how those donations were made. The question that needs to be asked is: if those donations were madeâand it is completely news to me if they wereâwhy were they not declared to the Electoral Commission?

In other parts of his evidence Mr Maguire says that over the years he has given something like $3,000 to $5,000 at most of my election campaigns. I was elected in 1991, 1995, 1998, 2001 and 2004. There is no evidence of any contribution under the Electoral Act that has been declared by Mr Maguire. So I call on the Senate inquiry while they are in Tamworth on the 29th of this month to bring Mr Maguire before the inquiry. Many members would not recognise that this is one of the few inquiries where evidence is given under sworn oath, and it is obvious from the evidence that Mr Maguire has givenâhis own evidenceâthat he is contradicting some of his own facts in this inquiry. I would urge the inquiry to look very closely at these matters and to call Mr Maguire.

Mr Maguire challenged this inquiry when he was in Canberra: âBring the inquiry to Tamworth,â he said. Mr Maguire also gave commitments that he would give details of his company names. He has not done that. He would have an opportunity on 29 June to do so. He said he would give documentation of donations that were made to my campaigns. He has not done that. The fact is that there is no evidence of such. Mr Maguire gave me some advice in 2001 about the placement of advertising slots. There has never been a financial contribution made. Mr Maguire has lied under oath before a Senate inquiry. I think that treatment of the Senate, of the inquiry and of the particular nature of this inquiry as one under sworn oath is something that really needs to be investigated.

On the broader issue, in terms of the way in which some of these issues have been played out, I think the Auditor-General should investigate the report that will come out in August from this inquiry as to the money trails, the background of some of these witnesses, the veracity of their evidence and their ability as individuals to give truthful evidenceâand I think some of that has been highlighted today. I have absolutely no problem opening any of my campaign books to the scrutiny of any inquiry that may take place, but I do believe that Mr Maguire needs to back up the statements that he made under oath before the Senate inquiry: that he made donations that would have been under company names. It would also be important for Mr Maguire to shine some illumination on the companies which are owned by Gregory Kevin Maguire, and other companies owned by Gregory Kenneth Maguire, both born on the same day in the same hospital. Are they, as a search that I have done indicates, the same individual? Does that have anything to do with the significance of some of the evidence? Does this person have two names that he is trading under, and is that a way of manoeuvring the truth in relation to which Maguire is answering which questions before the Senate inquiry?

Another matter I would like to raise in relation to the Regional Partnerships program goes to another issue. I think it gets to the heart of some of the issues where the government, particularly the Deputy Prime Minister and the parliamentary secretary, are trying to cover the path in terms of the processes that have been abused in relation to Regional Partnerships. I think the Senate inquiry will be interviewing the Chairman of the New England North West Area Consultative Committee while in Tamworth, and I appreciate that. But I see that the chairman, Kevin Humphriesâand it is no secret that Mr Humphries is to be the successor to Mr Anderson in the seat of Gwydir, so he will be showing great loyalty to Mr Anderson in this particular matterâreplied on 3 February to the committee concerning the area consultative committeeâs role in relation to the University of New England national centre for maths and science. Previously, many in this House would have presumed that the project was funded out of the Regional Partnerships project arrangement. Normally, under the due processes, the area consultative committee would have a role in the process of feeling out the various issues and determining whether it was appropriate that it be funded or not. Mr Humphries said in his letter to the committee:

quote.para: The project and associated fundingâ

speech.para: that is, the University of New England maths and science centre, a $4.95 million project, and a good project with which I had some involvementâ

quote.para: is not listed on our website. The projects listed on our website are to demonstrate the project capabilities, achievements and successes of the New England North West Area Consultative Committee. The Maths, Science, ICT project was not a project that we were involved in during its development or any of the funding process, except for comments we were asked to provide as above.

speech.para: Strange as it may seem, on 29 November 2004, heading up the project archive of this very same area consultative committee under âProjects funded 2003-04â, guess what we see? The National Centre for Science, Information Technology and Maths Education for Rural and Regional Australia has funding of $4.95 million. There is also a project description listed. If we fast forward to 24 January 2005âthat is, after this inquiry was startedâwe suddenly find that âProjects funded 2003-04â is headed up by the CWA Gunnedah Branch Building Extension. The maths and science centre has been airbrushed off the web site of the area consultative committee. I urge the committee to look into the various comments I have made today.

Mr Maguire said in evidence to the Senate inquiry that an inducement was made to me by him. He has admitted that there was the possibility of âjobs for the boysâ or an overseas posting. He suggested that I go and talk to John Anderson. That was within a few days of his having spent, on his admission, an hour and a halfâI believe it was longer than thatâwith the Deputy Prime Minister and Senator Sandy Macdonald discussing, amongst other things, the Regional Partnerships program and the future of the New England electorate. I believe there is evidence of contempt. I think the Senate inquiry, the Auditor-General and the parliament ought to look very closely at it, given the very special nature of the way in which evidence was accepted by the Senate inquiryâunder sworn oath, which is not the normal way that Senate inquiries operate within this particular parliament.

talk.start.para: âAs part of this debate on appropriations, I would like to make some comments on some issues within the sport portfolio. I would particularly like to focus on an issue which I think will be of growing importance into the future, and that is the involvement of women in sport. In May 2003, when opening a national forum on the need for more women in sport, Minister Rod Kemp said:

quote.para: Ensuring optimum involvement of women on and off the field makes good business sense for sport.

speech.para: â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦

quote.para: Sport needs to harness the skills and knowledge of as many women as possible.

speech.para: But what has happened since? Last year the government launched its women in sports leadership grants program, with $400,000 going to 192 recipients. That is a welcome initiative, well-received by the community. However, apart from this token action, what else has the government done to promote the greater involvement of women in sport? The situation has not changed. Visit most sporting venues across Australia and you will see on the walls countless photographs of male sporting champions but rarely will you see photographs of the women who have actively supported the club behind the scenes for decades as volunteers, coaches, team managers, scorers, timekeepers, committee members, fundraisers and in many other roles. One could argue that this is not unexpected, as most of the sporting facilities scattered across our nation are largely bastions of male sport.

Of course, this is not universal. There are many tennis, golf, bowls and a wide range of other sports clubs where male and female contributions are recognised. Whether they are recognised equally is another question, but at least in some sporting venues women do get some recognition, even if it is somewhat secondary to the recognition given to their male counterparts. But this secondary treatment of women in sport is not confined to the local level. How many members can remember seeing a review of Beyond the limits, Nicole Jefferyâs account of Australian hockey champion Alyson Annanâs remarkable career, when it was released last year? Not too many. To my knowledge, it was only reviewed in one Australian newspaperâand, even then, only in passing. I would like to read from the review because it raises some very interesting questions about the way women in sport are portrayed:

quote.para: At a time when lucrative publishing contracts seem standard issue for all new members of the Australian cricket team, you would think a biography of the worldâs greatest player in a sport would attract serious attention.
You would be rightâunless you were thinking about womenâs hockey, and Alyson Annan.

Some would say cricket is one of the most popular games, to play and to watch, in this country while hockey is played by fewer people and is less watchable. Perhaps, but letâs remember how few countries play Test cricket.

The Australian cricket team has been remarkably successful in the past decade, but so have the Hockeyroos, who won Olympic gold in 1988 (Seoul), 1996 (Atlanta) and 2000 (Sydney), the World Cup in 1994 and 1998 and the Champions Trophy in 1993, 1995 1997 and 1999.
Annan was the International Hockey Federationâs player of the year in 1998 and 2000, and has been a finalist in the world sportswoman of the year run by the Womenâs Sports Foundation.
Teammates and opponents say she does things on a hockey field they have never seen from any other player.
Her story has been told recently in Beyond the Limits â¦ by Nicole Jeffery, an award-winning sports journalist for The Australian who covered the past three Olympic Games.
Despite Annanâs achievements and Jefferyâs pedigree, you are reading the first review of Beyond the Limits in an Australian newspaper.

Womenâs sport, it seems, still does not rate as highly as menâs sport. Or, it doesnât without a sex scandal. After the Sydney Olympics, Channel Nineâs Sixty Minutes program ignored the world-beating Hockeyroos until they got wind of a story that Annan had left her husband for a woman (Carole Thate, captain of the Dutch hockey team).

The American journalist Janet Malcolm has written: âThe narratives of journalism, like those of mythology and folklore, derive their power from their firm, undeviating sympathies and antipathies. Cinderella must remain good and the stepsisters bad. âSecond stepsister not so bad after all,â is not a good story.â

A gay woman hockey player clicks into the Lego set story kit produced by Sixty Minutes. A group of supremely talented, fit women whose ferocity and obsession with their hockey thoroughly unnerved opponents (according to Carole Thate as reported by Jeffery) is not a good story.

Hereâs an even less good story: there is an argument, supported by statistics compiled by Australiaâs doyen of Olympic historians, Harry Gordon, that Australian women have consistently and substantially outperformed Australian men at the Olympics.
The menâs hockey team, while often highly rated, has not won Olympic gold.

speech.para: This article was written prior to the last Olympics when, good on them, the men did win gold.

quote.para: Imagine that: a nation of sports-mad macho blokes outdone by a bunch of sheilas.

speech.para: I read that article into the record to make some points about how you can view some of these issues, although I would not necessarily agree with all of what is in the review. It does raise some very interesting points. Jefferyâs book never got the same boost as books about male sports stars such as Mark Waugh or Shane Warne inevitably receive from the media. It never got into the top sellers list, not because Annanâs story was not worth telling but because it did not get the attention it deserved. Why? Because it was about a female champion in a sport which most Australians think about only when the Olympic Games or Commonwealth Games come about.

The profile of womenâs sport in Australia remains a blight on our proud hsitory of sporting achievement. Interestingly, much of our international sports history has been built on the basis of female champions. Most Australians can name female Olympic champions such as Dawn Fraser, Cathy Freeman, Betty Cuthbert, Marjorie Jackson, Jane Flemming, Shane Gould and Tracey Wickham much less Murray Rose or even Kieren Perkins. In sports such as tennis and golf the reverse probably applies, with Greg Norman far better known than Karrie Webb or Pat Cash being remembered more than, say, Yvonne Gooligong.

Irrespective of the sporting context, the fact of the matter is that we have a national sporting tradition built on a concept of masculinity, but in reality women have made an equal if not more important contribution to our international sporting reputation. Given this situation, why is it that womenâs sport is so poorly supported by both the government and the private sector? Womenâs sport cannot attract the same level of sponsorship as menâs sport. It is easy to blame this situation on the media, particularly television and the poor coverage given of womenâs sport, but it is not as simple as this. Some sections of the mediaâmainly the print mediaâare giving more coverage to womenâs sport today than ever before, but more still needs to be done.

The government needs to get more active in supporting womenâs sport and promoting the role women play in sport both on the field and off it. Women need help from the government to get a better go. To give an example, it is estimated that each of the members of the menâs Australian cricket team earns more than $1 million per year. When Australiaâs women cricketers returned to Australia from South Africa in April this year, having cruised undefeated to their fifth World Cup title, it was back to work. The players have real jobs. In fact, it is only since womenâs cricket has been integrated with Cricket Australia that women have had all of their overseas travel expenses covered. While this represents some progress, it is still a very poor situation.

Womenâs sport needs investment in facilities across Australia and more money put into encouraging young women to participate in sport and to continue that participation as they grow older. At the last election, Labor pledged to commit $2.4 million over four years to re-establish a womenâs sports unit within the ASC. We made this commitment because we believe it is essential that something be done to improve equity for women in both community based and elite sport. We are also committed to raising the status and profile of female athletes in the eyes of Australians. If we can achieve this, perhaps some of the financial support that flows from the private sector to male sports can be redirected to womenâs sport.

While women have made some gains in recent years, they remain underrepresented in most areas of sport. They also remain underrecognised and underresourced. Labor is committed to changing this situation. Labor believes that a dedicated unit that works with industry to break down the barriers and improve access opportunities for women in sport is essential to achieve a genuine acceptance of women in sport, particularly in advanced coaching, administration and officiating roles. A womenâs sport unit could have a significant role to play in creating a safe and supportive environment for all female participants by developing strategies to eliminate all forms of harassment and abuse in sport. In line with its commitment to womenâs sporting opportunities, Labor has also committed to the restoration of the Prime Ministerâs Women in Sport Award, which was scrapped by the Howard government.

A lot more can be done and a lot more should be done in this area. It makes good sense for governments to look at this and for industry to see what can be done. At a conference in 2003 on this issue, some comments were made about the issue of the good business sense of involving women. An article in the Canberra Times of 21 May 2003 stated:

quote.para: It made smart business sense to have more women involved at all levels of Australian sport, a national forum for the industry heard yesterday.
Speaking at Sport Needs More Women, the Australian Sports Commissionâs chief executive officer Mark Peters said that attention needed to be drawn to womenâs success in general business.
âResearch shows that businesses owned and operated by women have higher survival rates and tend to make a profit earlier than new businesses started by men,â Peters said.
Much of this had to do with womenâs management styles, he said, citing rugby league as an example of a sport increasingly turning to women coaches at the junior level.

âThey have a more inclusive style, well-honed negotiating skills, excellent organising and budgeting abilities and a natural gift for communication with both the kids and the parents,â Peters said.
He said business in general survived and thrived by seeking out new markets and developing strategies for tapping those markets.

âFor the sports industry, even a rudimentary analysis of the market would tell them that to achieve greater long-term sustainability and viability, they need more women involved at all levels,â he said.
âNot just in playing, but in administration, marketing, coaching and officiating.â
Peters said that ASC data for between 1999 to 2000 showed that 24.6 per cent of women over the age of 18 took part in organised sport and physical activities, compared with 33.3 per cent of men.

The data also showed last year that 10 women, compared with 50 men, were at executive director level in national sporting organisations, and the statistics for other senior positions were similarly disproportionate, Peters said.

speech.para: I think that article makes some very relevant points about the question of why it is important that we try to expand the involvement of women in sport across the board. It goes to the question of not only being able to make those sports run better but also being able to ensure that we get a wider participation in organised sport across genders. There is a range of issues related to this question of what to do to try to make it easier for women to be involved in sport, and there has been quite a bit written about that. An article from a publication citing the ASC National Policy on Women and Girls in Sport, Recreation and Physical Activity, 1999-2000 states:

quote.para: So how do we tailor sports to suit the needs of women and to keep them involved as lifelong participants? As with any particular target group, it is important to investigate what women and girls want from their sporting experience, rather than assuming we already know. If there are certain issues that are preventing females from being involved in sport or physical activity, then naturally these need to be addressed.
The following issues have been identified as limiting female participation in sport and physical activity:
Lack of childcare facilities
Uncomfortable or revealing uniforms/clothing
Amount of time involved
Too competitive
Poor perception of their ability
Poor body image

speech.para: So there is quite a bit that can done and quite a bit that should be done. This is something that we ought to be looking at from the governmental point of view as to what we can achieve in improving the way we manage sport in this country and improving the outcomes we can get in the wider community. When we look at sports like netball and hockey, we can see that our women are up there with the very best in the world. You have only to go along to some of their eventsâand I know from going along to see one of the netball tests some months agoâto see that they work very hard and that they are incredibly professional, given the time they can dedicate to their sport and given what else they have to do to support themselves in the meantime. I would certainly commend any members who get the opportunity to go out there and have a look at what women are doing in these areas and they will see that there is more that we as a parliament should be doing to try and assist them to do the very best they can for our country.

talk.start.para: âI take this opportunity today to outline some of the failings that I see in the Howard governmentâs 2005 budget, particularly how it is framed in terms of the needs of people in my electorate. A budget tells us a lot about a government. It tells us about a governmentâs priorities, its values and its vision for the country. And so it was with this latest budget. Unfortunately, it told us what we already knew about this government: its priorities are looking after its rich mates and making life harder for those already facing disadvantage, while its vision never goes beyond scoring political points.

speech.para: There is nothing in the budget that demonstrates an appreciation of the challenges facing our country or of the investment that is required to set us up for the future. This is a budget which proves again the short-sightedness of the Howard government. Of course, it is a budget which offered middle-income earners a tiny $6 a week tax cut while providing high-income earners with 10 times that amount.

It should be noted that, even with the $22 billion to be spent on personal tax cuts in the budget, the government is still up there as the highest taxing government in Australiaâs history. The average taxpayer now pays $12,000 more annually in taxes than they did prior to the Howard government coming to office. As proof of the unfairness of these latest tax cuts and this governmentâs determination to ensure that the rich get richer, 45 per cent of these tax cuts are going to the top 10 per cent of taxpayers. And the government wonders why the Labor Party is in the Senate today trying to amend those tax cuts to make them much fairer for the vast majority of Australian taxpayers.

While the 2005 budget may have been received with cheers in electorates like Higgins and Wentworth, this budget was not well received in my electorate of Capricornia. Like the rest of regional Australia, Capricornia has been left out by a government that is too intent on looking after only the big end of town while abandoning the rest of us to the scraps left over, which are usually in the form of politically motivated pork-barrelling, with no serious thought given to the needs and opportunities that exist in our region of Central Queensland.

The budget did not address any of the issues that would make a difference to the lives of the people in Capricornia and to the prospects of our region going into the futureâfrom the need for greater spending on health and education right through to the very great need for improving the roads leading to the Shoalwater Bay military training area. There is nothing in the budget that will deliver better services or help us to build on the opportunities that we have identified as the key to our future success. But this budget has provided the people of Central Queensland with one clear certaintyâthat is, the poor will get poorer under this government.

Capricornia has a poverty rate of 12.6 per cent, which equates to 16,563 people in Central Queensland living below the poverty line. The budget gives no hope to these people. There is no increase in their income and no support for the services that they need to live decent lives and to aspire to a better future. It is obvious that the government are not interested in helping the poorest people in our community. They just want to score some political points off them by reducing their income and making life even harder for them. But those people targeted by the government are not taking the attacks against them lying down. Since the budget was announced in May, my office has been inundated with calls from disability support pensioners and sole parents who have been shocked by the news that their income support benefits from Centrelink could be taken off them. Some of them are also concerned that they will be forced to relocate to other parts of the country to find jobs.

While the Treasurer stood across the chamber and delivered his budget speech, the people of regional Australia waited to hear a budget of reformâa budget of infrastructure investment and investment in our people through greater spending on education and the delivery of a reasonable health service. But the people of Central Queensland, my electorate of Capricornia, together with the rest of regional Australia were sorely disappointed by this Treasurer.

I want to draw the Houseâs attention to a couple of key areas where this government has failed to listen to the needs of the people of Central Queensland. These are matters which could and should have been addressed in the budget. On numerous occasions in the recent past I have stood in this chamber to represent those people in my electorate who live near the Shoalwater Bay military training area. Their issues concern the condition of their roads, particularly after a major military training exercise has taken place at Shoalwater Bay. For example, right now there is a joint US-Australian military exercise going on at Shoalwater Bay involving some 17,000 troops, so you can imagine the pressure that is putting on the surrounding infrastructure. While it is true that the Department of Defence does provide some make-good funding to the Livingstone Shire Council to assist with road repairs at Shoalwater Bay, undertaking the required upgrading works will actually result in long-term savings of approximately one-third of the annual maintenance cost of the existing gravel roads.

It is estimated that Defence Force exercises at the Shoalwater Bay training area inject $10 million into our regional economy every year. This figure is significantly more when, as we are doing at the moment, we are hosting joint exercises with US defence forces. In addition there are significant multiplier effects for the wider economy of Central Queensland, including an estimated $7 million expended through military tourism in the region every year. So there is quite broad support in the community for these exercises, but there is also a very strong and growing recognition by the community surrounding Shoalwater Bay that the costs of the exercises and the pressure that is placed on the infrastructure should not be borne by them alone and that there should be a fair contribution made by the federal government towards these exercises, which are in the interests of all Australians in terms of building our defence capability. To date, the government has instead chosen to ignore the plight of the people living in the vicinity of Shoalwater Bay. In fact, local residents are now describing themselves as the neglected collateral damage of all the joint US-Singaporean-Australian armed forces exercises.

In the run-up to the last election the Labor Party committed $15.5 million to fixing this problem. We were keen to work with the local government authority to upgrade the roads to a decent standard, to make sure that they are safe and reasonable for both military personnel and local people. At the time of the election we challenged the government to follow suit and match that funding. However, visits by the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anderson, and the Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation, Senator Ian Macdonald, saw themâas usualâpromising everything and delivering nothing. The government have still made no commitments to improving this vital military infrastructure. Sadly, they have similarly made no such commitment in this budget. However, I am convinced that even this government must realise the great need for these roadworks and today I am again writing, on behalf of the local residents as well as the Defence Force personnel involved, to the Minister for Defence, urging him to please attend to the Shoalwater Bay roads as a matter of urgency.

Before the last election Labor made a commitment to reintroduce the Commonwealth Dental Health Program and I, along with many other members on this side of the House, have asked the government to reconsider its position on this vital program. This government abolished the Commonwealth Dental Health Program when it came to office in 1996. It thereby condemned many Australians to long periods of misery and poor general health as a consequence of the long delays that are experienced in the now critically underfunded and unsupported state dental health programs. This budget was an opportunity for the government to reintroduce that Commonwealth funding but it appears that once again the opportunity has been missed. As a consequence there are people in my electorateâlike Mrs Johannensen of Rockhamptonâwho are condemned to further suffering. Mrs Johannensen had a tooth pulled in August 2004 and was told she needed a filling in another tooth. She has her name on the waiting list and is still waiting to have that tooth filled. Mrs Johannensen, like so many other people, has nowhere to go; she must just put up with it. She is just another casualty of the governmentâs indifference to people on low incomes.

Of course there are another 500,000 Australians like Mrs Johannensen on waiting lists for dental care. Apart from causing those individuals unnecessary pain and suffering, it is just plain bad health policy. Dr David Curnow from the Victorian branch of the Australian Dental Association recently stated:

quote.para: â¦ even waiting one year for dental treatment is likely to lead to unacceptable oral and general health outcomes.

speech.para: Laborâs plan would have seen $300 million being injected into a Commonwealth dental plan in a positive attempt to clear the backlog of patients waiting to see a dentist. This plan would have been a return to the highly successful program initiated by the Keating government that even the current Minister for Health and Ageing has deemed a success.

Compounding the problem in dental health is the steady decline in the number of dentists in Australia, and particularly the difficulties in getting dentists to regional parts. It is now predicted that there will be a shortage of 1,500 dental workers by 2010. It is the height of social irresponsibility that this government, crowing about the budget surplus on one hand, could not find $300 million in this budget to reintroduce the Commonwealth Dental Health Program, which would make such a difference to so many people in my electorate.

The other great concern for people in Central Queensland is the shortage of doctors in our regional communities. There is certainly nothing in the budget to improve access to health services for the people living in my electorate. In fact, affordable health care is getting further out of reach. On budget night the Treasurer put the final nail in the coffin of the health ministerâs rock solid, ironclad guarantee about the Medicare safety net. The governmentâs safety net is now in tatters and people face even higher costs to see a GP if, indeed, there is a doctor to see in their town.

It is obvious that this government simply does not understand what it means to live in a regional town without a doctor. In my electorate, the mining town of Blackwater has just been through that situation and, even now, has less than adequate services. Blackwater is the service town for major coalmining operations in the Bowen Basin. The permanent population of Blackwater is 5Â½ thousand people, with a construction work force of 1,000 people. The majority of the working population is associated with high-risk coalmining operations. Blackwater has been without a permanent doctor for several weeks now. By a twist of fate, a Blackwater mine worker sustained severe head injuries at work on the very first day that the Blackwater hospital was left without a doctor. The miner was taken to Blackwater hospital, where there was no doctor to assess him; he was assessed by the nurses. He was transferred by ambulance to the Emerald hospital, which is 75 kilometres from Blackwater, where he was then assessed by a doctor. After this assessment, he was flown to the Royal Brisbane Hospital. The miner was conscious throughout this ordeal, despite being very badly hurt.

Obviously, if a doctor had been on duty in Blackwater this injured worker would have been flown directly from Blackwater to Brisbane rather than having his treatment delayed by having to go to Emerald first for a doctorâs assessment. Coalmining is a very dangerous occupation, and we have every reason to be concerned about medical services available to our miners. In the district of Blackwater there are many other people involved in rural industry on farms which, of course, also have very high rates of injuryâoften very serious injuries. So it is not only the miners but also the local farmers and their families who are at risk. I will quote from a letter I have received from Mrs Harris of Blackwater, who writes:

quote.para: On the 13 May 2004 my son Mitchell was hospitalised with severe respiratory failure. He was stabilized by the medical staff in Blackwater before being transported to Rockhampton base hospitalâ

speech.para: Rockhampton Base Hospital is almost 200 kilometres east of Blackwaterâ

quote.para: He spent 6 and a half weeks in hospital between Rockhampton and the Royal Brisbane 4 of those weeks in the Intensive care unit on life support.

He was critically ill. My concerns are this â¦ if this happened today my son would be dead. The initial care he received kept him going, if there had not been a doctor available I wouldnât like to imagine what would have happened. Donât the ordinary people of Blackwater deserve to have decent medical care?

My sonâs condition was of rapid onset. He was well on Sunday but on life support by Thursday. It is not fair to expect nurses to cope with the pressure of this, they are not doctors. If there is anything to be done to rectify this situation could you please do so?

speech.para: In support of Mrs Harris, today I wrote to the health minister inviting him to the mining town of Blackwater and asking for his assistance to help find a permanent doctor for this mining town.

Other sections of our community are also in great need of assistance with doctors. The Bidgerdii Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Community Health Service was established in Rockhampton in 1995 to service the Central Queensland Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community. It does a fantastic job. Over the years it has broadened its services to much needed areas such as nutrition and eye health. Bidgerdii recently established a new clinic in the central highlands in an effort to better address the health needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people throughout Central Queensland. However, in its 10 years of excellent service it has never received funding to cover the salary of its general practitioner in Rockhampton. This is unlike other similar Aboriginal health services that do receive money for GP salaries, and this assists their ability to attract and retain GPs to work not only in the area of patient illnesses but also in the much needed areas of preventative health programs and other health related promotions such as substance abuse, domestic violence and prenatal and antenatal care.

Bidgerdii understands the need for it to deliver such services to its community and it is an absolute credit to the management committee and staff at Bidgerdii that they have been providing this service without proper funding for 10 years. But it is being unfairly prevented from doing the extra work it has identified and knows needs to be done for the Indigenous community in Central Queensland because it has simply never been given appropriate funding. It has never been given funding for GP salaries in the same way that other Aboriginal health services have. The staff at Bidgerdii are working very hard to provide a high-quality service and it is high time the government gave Bidgerdii the support it deserves to meet the enormous need for affordable and appropriate health care for the Indigenous community in Central Queensland.

In coming back to the neglect of regional Australia by this government, I have to say it has tried to act like a friend to the regions by rolling out its pork-barrel political slush fund called Regional Partnerships. We have seen very clearly the partnership involved in this funding scamâit is the partnership between money and votes. This government was more than happy to throw around money to regional areas prior to last yearâs election, providing of course that the electorates that received money were marginal seats. This budget represents a wasted opportunity for this government to do something positive in regional Australia and give a little back to the areas that make Australia the wealthy country that it is. This government had the opportunity to put forward a real plan for infrastructure development in the regions, a plan to end the bottlenecks in our transport sectors and to commit to road projects of significance. The government has once again failed to address regional Australiaâs development needs.

The one thing this government can claim as a success for this budget is that it will continue to gradually increase the inequality now so obvious in all parts of the country. Under the Howard government, the contrast between rich and poor grows each year, and this year will be no exception. As it happens, just as I was heading out of my office to give this speech I noticed I had received in the mail the Comet, which is the newsletter of the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants League in Queensland. I turned to the regular column put in by the President, Yvonne Zardani, who does great work as an advocate for pensioners and superannuants in our state. I would like to finish by reading out some of the observations that Mrs Zardani made on the budget. We are in here debating Laborâs view of the budget and the coalitionâs view of the budget, and it all gets very predictable and almost a bit artificial, although there are very strongly held views. But here is someone who is out there working in the community every day and who is speaking directly from the real world. This is what Mrs Zardani had to say about the budget:

quote.para: The budget was not a surprise for most people, we all realise that lower income people are not on the agenda for this Federal Government. I felt there was real contempt in Mr Costelloâs voice in delivering the changes to the welfare benefits.

speech.para: She goes on to say:

quote.para: Most sole parents are people who have been divorcedâvery few keep having children to collect a pension. I know of a young family, with both parents working and 2 children. The mother is a nurse, which as you know, means shiftwork. Up until now the children have been going to after-school and holiday care, but they just canât afford it any longer. The children are now coming home on the bus to an empty home and will be spending the next school holidays at home alone for the first time. If this is happening in a middle-income family, please tell me how a sole parent will cope?

speech.para: Maybe Mr Costello would like to answer that question. Mrs Zardani goes on:

quote.para: There are thousands of children whoâve grown up in a jobless family, but their parents have the same aspirations that we all have for our children. Simple things like feeding and clothing them, giving them an education and seeing them do better than themselves. Itâs not much to ask.

speech.para: She finishes by saying:

quote.para: The divide between the rich and poor is now even wider. There is nothing for schools or university students.
â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦

Medicare did not get any help. God help anyone who canât afford health care cover, and even with health care you still pay more. There is nothing for oral health. Nothing for housing. Not a very bright future for those who are on limited funds.

speech.para: Good on you, Mrs Zardani, for speaking out. Those of us on this side of the House are right in there with you advocating on behalf of the low-income earners in this community. As for me, I am advocating for the people of regional Australia like those in Central Queensland in my electorate. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI want to begin this contribution to the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2005-2006 and related bills by referring to the so-called âdemocratic processesâ seen in the House today. If they are a portent of what we can expect post July, when the government controls both houses, then pity help us. If there is to be no debate in the House on top of no amendments, and the same in the Senate, then we have a one-party state. The skills crisis in this country has been one of the most talked about issues over the past 18 months, but now we have seen the government shut down debate on its so-called solution, denying many members the opportunity to contribute. I was one of those. My staff have worked long and hard researching this issue. Not only was my contribution to this important debate stymied by a gag but, when I attempted to speak to an amendment moved by the minister to correct a major drafting blunder in the explanatory memorandum, I was again denied a chance to speak even though I had received the call from the Deputy Speaker, notwithstanding the fact that the process involved the minister coming first.

speech.para: Fortuitously, because this debate was happening at the time, I can record some of my observations on those bills here. Under the Skilling Australiaâs Workforce Bill 2005 and the Skilling Australiaâs Workforce (Repeal and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2005, the government will dismantle the very successful and independent Australian National Training Authority, which has developed a consistent vocational education and training system across the country. ANTA worked because it included all playersâindustry, government, unions and trainersâand distributed funding where it was needed. The government itself acknowledged that ANTAâs success had been established by publicly announcing that it was âa truly national vocational education and training system with industry leadershipâ.

The bills on which debate was truncated in the House today give the Commonwealth direct control over where VET funding goes and attach a raft of conditions, such as forcing its workplace agenda on TAFE and channelling public money to private training providers. It is an ideological straitjacket for the states and territories if they do not want to lose what amounts to a third of their total funding needs for VET and TAFE. So much for cooperative federalism! ANTA is not responsible for the skills shortage in this country. That results from government and industry reluctance to invest in real apprenticeshipsânot short-term training with dubious qualifications, at worst exploited as a means of low-income employees. The honest and realistic sectors of industry now admit they have been selfish and short-sighted when it comes to real investment in real skills for our young. The government is refusing to recognise the impact globalisation and international competition are having on our training programs and skilling.

There have been huge shifts from government to private ownership in the running of utilities. Electricity, transport, roads and defence manufacturing are just some of the areas, particularly so in my electorate, where apprenticeships traditionally provided thousands of young people with opportunities over the years. Indeed, the former apprenticeship school at Wallerawang power station was one of the largest in the country. As with Telecom, now Telstra, so much of the work of formerly public utilities is now contracted out, with a sensational associated drop in the level of commitment to training young people. Global competition has seen the bottom line become all important and cost cuts have included apprenticeship training. Industry, by and large, has preferred to subcontract specific units of work to smaller business, which results in more subcontractors who simply cannot afford to take on apprentices.

I see nothing in the governmentâs proposals for skilling the work force that addresses this reality in any real and sensible way, apart perhaps from the bonus being offered to existing apprentices to stay on. We need more real apprenticeships and real training wages, not labour imported just in time, and we need to allocate scarce training resources by the fairest possible means. ANTA provided that; the governmentâs approach in the gagged bills does not. The structure to combat the skills shortage by way of an independent ANTA process is now being dismantled to suit short-term political objectives rather than the long-term skilling needs of the country.

I have spoken elsewhere in another debate about the inequity of the tax cuts delivered in this budget. However, I want to add a few words following the release of the St Vincent de Paul social issues paper on the reality of income inequality in Australia. Amid new reports of a $37 million retirement package for a bank managerâfor that is what he isâand an $11 million package for Telstraâs new CEO and amid other signs of the rapidly escalating gap between the haves and have-nots of this country, our Prime Minister continues, along with other government ministers, to spin the myth that we are still the egalitarian country, the fair country of the fair go.

The Vinnies report is a thorough examination of the real maths, not the selective quoting of data that is used when we are told that low-income households have enjoyed the strongest growth in private incomes over the period 1997-98 to 2004-05. The St Vincent de Paul report states:

quote.para: Assertions that income inequality is moderating are based on the use of averages and percentages, which disguise an unequal growth in income reflected in absolute terms, especially at the lowest levels.

speech.para: In concentrating solely on income inequality, St Vinnies lays aside other significant factors of inequality, such as health services, housing, education, child and aged care services, transport and communications, and social exclusion.

The St Vincent de Paul report suggests that Australian high-income households enjoy lifestyles at unbelievable levels above the norm, while low-income households are deprived of opportunities to break free from their disadvantage. Using data from the Bureau of Statistics, the report highlights how eight million Australians, or 42 per cent of the population, have equivalised disposable incomes of less than $21,000 per annum. Of these eight million Australians, 4Â½ million are in households with an aggregate income of less than $400 a week. Again the report shows that the ratio of top incomes to low incomes has consistently worsened over the past nine years. The report also says:

quote.para: Confirmation of the ABS data can be found in the Gini coefficient, used internationally to measure income equality â¦
For Australia, the Gini coefficient has deteriorated from 0.296 in 1996/7 to 0.309 in 2002/3 ... a strong shift to greater inequality.

speech.para: There was not one question from the opposition the day this report was released. There was no story on the national Channel 9 news and no report on ABC television. A large slice of the media should be ashamed. They swallow the government misinformation and do not even report this most basic and objective counterargument which is so important to understanding what is occurring in Australiaâthat is, the fostering of privilege over need.

Let me relate just one story from a constituent that highlights the impact on sole parent payments of changes announced in the budget. Cheryl from Lithgow says that looking after school-age kids requires a lot of time for a single parent, quite apart from the days children are sick or on school vacation. In Lithgow and other parts of the central west there is simply not enough paid part-time work to go around, quite apart from transport difficulties should a position become available, perhaps in Bathurst 50 kilometres down the road. The unavailability and expense of child care is also a major hurdle.

Cheryl says many single parents already do a lot of unpaid work in various capacities, especially relating to school, with tuckshop work, reading assistance programs and other community activities. It should be remembered by Treasurers wanting to get single mothers back to work that volunteers, who are often single mothers, save the Australian taxpayers about $40 billion a yearâmore than our GST receipts. How, one might ask, will those voluntary hours be filled?

Indeed, the member for Ryan made this very point in the adjournment debate a few weeks ago in underlining the unsung contribution volunteers make to our economyâa greater contribution, I might say, than the misguided attempts to force volunteers among the ranks of single mothers onto the job market and the social costs that may incur. Cheryl says that if the new legislation does not recognise all forms of voluntary work and assumes every single mum can get a friend or a relative to look after an unwell child, or a latchkey kid for that matter, then the emotional burden placed on sole parents will be huge.

Why canât this policy account at least for volunteer work as being equivalent to the activities test in the same way as it is applied to senior job seekers who do not qualify for the pension or access to retirement accounts? Why canât a continued parenting payment rather than so-called enhanced, but in fact lower paying, Newstart be retained for those demonstrating the commitment to voluntary effort that Cheryl demonstrates? Quite apart from that, why this punishment for those whose sole role is parenting? Is that regarded as some sort of voluntary activity? We hear so much about family dysfunction and about the need for family values, yet here we see a government undertaking a bit of political wedging, of social engineering, based largely on the prejudice of those in the community who regard single mothers as welfare bludgers.

Apart from that, we are driving those who manage to find work into financial difficulties. According to opposition figures, which I presume are reasonably accurate, a single parent with two children working 15 hours a week will be approximately $70 a week worse off, while a single parent with two children working 20 hours a week will be $90 a week worse off and with four children, $120 a week worse off. I realise the Jobs, Education and Training child-care provisions are designed to assist low-income families meet any gap in child-care fees, and they are obviously welcome, but I want to comment on other child-care changes. While 84,300 additional outside school hours places are welcome, where are the during school hours places and where are the jobs between 10 o clock and two oâclock for mums who need to pick up and deliver their kids? It is a nonsense that the part-time work that many mothers may getâand that is at best, in my electorateâwill somehow magically lead to full-time work, as one minister has suggested. The child-care infrastructure is just not available to cater for extra places, even if parents could afford it. As in aged care, the guarantee of funding is no guarantee the physical accommodation can or will be provided.

I want to also say that there is major concern within the community over the continued failure of state and federal governments to adequately fund public dental services, as the previous speaker mentioned. The Rural Dental Action Group formed in the central west wants to work in a constructive way with government to ensure one of our health black holesâdental care for lower income earnersâis addressed to overcome a crisis that has developed since the end of the federally funded scheme in 1996. I appreciate one of the major concerns is the training of dentists and the cost of getting professors of dentistry at universities at only a fraction of the price they could obtain in private practice. It is a huge problem and it goes to the nub of the difficulty in supplying enough dentists to the system. I understand that. But, despite its denials over the years since 1996, the government does have constitutional authorityâI would say responsibilityâunder section 51(xxiiiA) of the Constitution to provide adequate dental care. This power was specifically given to the Commonwealth in a 1946 referendum. The Medicare concession for urgent cases, granted last year, is a start but represents a drop in the ocean compared with the need.

The federal governmentâs drought package will certainly ease some of the pain of what has been described as the worst drought in a century. Hopefully the rain of recent days is a portent of the many inches yet required to go anywhere near restoring hope for some better seasons and replenishing critical town water supplies, particularly along the Lachlan River in my electorate. The definition of exceptional circumstances needs urgent attention to ensure a fair application of assistance. While farm organisations have been calling for a cash grant process, a fairer and more affordable scheme all aroundâand one more acceptable to the taxpayer, I suggestâwould be an interest-free âpay back in good timesâ arrangement like HECS, as some independent commentators have suggested.

While our overseas competitors like Japan, the United States and Europe continue to support their farmers in good timesâEuropeans could only have nightmares about the drought that we are experiencingâsupport for efficient farm families is totally justified. Efficiency and sustainabilityâecological as well as economic sustainabilityâare the keys. If farmers do not pass that test, they should not be entrusted with our fragile and drought prone land. It is as simple as that.

I am in the process of again surveying my electorate on their views on the full sale of Telstra and their views on the adequacy or not of the network. I will not prejudge the outcome, but I suspect there has been a hardening of opposition to the full sale. Things are nowhere near up to scratch, whatever that means. Even those close to the telecommunications coalface suggest that we are way off any sort of measurement of anything that may mean up to scratch. Shortcomings in mobile services and installations, lousy internet connection with expensive options as the only solution and nowhere near an adequate exchange network to provide ADSLâthe stories keep coming into my office from all over the state. New Telstra CEO Trujilloâs suggestion of local government-Telstra partnerships is code for getting rid of the difficult solutions. People want continued regulation across the board, and I suspect that 90 per cent or thereabouts of my electorate will again say they want continued public oversight and government control.

The Treasurerâs forecast that the federal government will be close to debt free by next June contradicts his stated position that Telstra should be sold and the proceeds used to retire government debt. Country people have consistently refused to countenance the sale of an infrastructure and service they regard as vital to their long-term communication requirements and those of their childrenâquite apart from the several billion dollars in dividends their telco can deliver to the public purse from a public asset. Nothing they have heard from the government and its allies at the top end of townâthe infrastructure piratesâwill convince most country folk otherwise. So let it be known to all government membersâI know the member for Hinkler, who is at the table, is very committed to our telecommunications needs and aware of their shortcomingsâthat they dare sell Telstra only in the face of overwhelming public opposition.

As for the Future Fund established by budget initiatives, the feedback I get is that, while provision for future infrastructure needs is wise, the risking of billions of dollars of public money, especially the proceeds of a Telstra sale, is unacceptable. A likely correction in the US economy could well wipe several billion dollars off that fund in one fell swoop. I am one of those who see no economic danger in sensible public borrowings for essential infrastructure.

Finally, I wish to acknowledge the recent Reconciliation Australia Conference here in Canberra and its focus on the way forward in achieving a just outcome for our Indigenous people. I quote the words of Pat Dodson at one forum session I attended:

quote.para: Efforts that were made by decent people in 1967 to gain a fair and just position for us in this nation have not resulted in any meaningful negotiation or resolution of our place in this nation.

speech.para: A few days before hearing Pat Dodson, I had the pleasure of launching Treaty, a serious study of the treaty processes in Canada, the US and New Zealand and whether such a process is a way forward in this country. It is written by highly respected authors Larissa Behrendt; Sean Brennan, previously of the Parliamentary Library here; Lisa Strelein; and George Williams. I commend it to all who are or should be interested in this issue. At the launch I said:

quote.para: We have towns competing for the economic benefits of new jailsâencouraged by law and order Premiers and politiciansâjails to house the overwhelming number of Indigenous inmates; jails designed to be closer to Indigenous communitiesâa tragic twist on âbringing them homeâ.

speech.para: I also said:

quote.para: Unless modern Australia forges a treaty with its original custodians, we have no claim to moral or legal legitimacy. Instead of seeking our identity and the birth of our nation at Gallipoli, let us go back to 1770 and complete the job we should have done then.

talk.start.para: âThe Liberal government came to power riding on the debt truck. Their major promotion in the election campaign was the debt truckâa quite valid comment. The Labor government came in when the debt was some $25,000 million and the debt in their nine or 10 years or whatever it was in office rolled up to $186,000 million. So it was quite a valid comment, because that money has to be repaidâAustralians have to repay the principal and the interest. Having said that, I note we do not hear anything about the debt truck today. I am a public admirer of the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, and remain so, but I must say that, unfortunately for him, the history books are not going to treat very kindly the performance of this government. They are not going to treat it very well because it was really under this regime that we had an explosion in our balance of payments. Unfortunately for this government, they are reaping the results of the handiwork of Mr Keating in deregulating the economy. But, quite justifiably, the criticism will fall upon the shoulders of this government and upon the head of this government because they continued those policies. There was no amelioration, there was no pull-back and there was no vision of the impending disaster with the current account and our balance of payments.

speech.para: All of these are high-flying and high-sounding words with macro figures that we do not understand, but what we do understand is that this government remains committed to bringing in bananas from overseas. The minister has been tenacious in his commitment to destroying an industry worth $350 million to the Australian economy. Mr Deputy Speaker Baldwin, you would recall the announcements that chicken meat was coming into this country and, quite frankly, chicken meat would have come into this country except for your endeavours. If it had, we would have had the aviary diseaseâbird flu, as it is calledâand almost certainly we would have also had an outbreak of Newcastle disease, based on the scientific information that you placed at the time before the Prime Minister and other parties involved. But the announcement had already been made by the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anderson, that the chicken meat was coming in. I understand this issue because 150 jobs in my electorate depended upon that announcement. We had already seen 2,000 jobs removed with the deregulation of tobaccoâpeople in Australia still smoke and the difference now is that they smoke overseas tobaccoâand another 150 jobs were to go from that same town. Now another 5,000 jobs will go from the coastal areas of my electorate, but the government does not seem to get the message.

Larry Anthony, an excellent member of parliament in every wayâa very humane, decent and intelligent personâlost his seat to the Labor Party partially because it was in what was historically a banana-growing area. Everyone knew that the governmentâparticularly the National Party, which held the relevant portfoliosâwas determined to see that those bananas were going to come in, even though their own assessment tribunal said, no, the bananas should not come in. Then forces were brought to bear and the decision was reversed. An all-party committeeâall parties in the Senate were represented on the committeeâhas condemned stridently the incompetence of and the mistakes made by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, and the courts of Australia condemned AQIS again, on the issue of the pork, last week or the week before. We have government ministers who are determined to wreck the economy of Australia. There is issue after issue on which these people are determined that imports will be given a rails ride and that exports, when you try to get something out of this country, will be a nightmare. They put up a barbed wire entanglement which does not allow anything to go out, but then they pull the barbed wire entanglement away when anything is to come into this country.

Agricultural industries have to compete against an average support level in subsidy tariffs of 49 per cent. These are OECD figures. The support level in Australia is six per cent. And that is with the milk levy, which vanishes over the next two or three yearsâso it will be down around three per cent. Our farmers are expected to be 45 per cent better than their international competitors. They are better, but the sad thing is that they are not 45 per cent better. They cannot compete and they will not compete. We simply see great industries, such as the wool industry, collapsing. Half of the sheep population in Australia has gone. Twenty-five per cent of the cattle population has gone. Last time I looked, dairying was down about 10 per centâand it is early years yet as far as deregulation of the dairying industry goes. The sugar industry is in a state of freefall, and that is no secret to anyone in Australia. Industry after industry is collapsing simply because they cannot compete against a 45 per cent advantage.

Let me not pass judgment upon the performance of the government. Let me mention Mr Keating, who was Treasurer for the best part of a decade or more and the Prime Minister of Australia. When the current account hit $15,000 million Mr Keating said that Australia was in danger of becoming a banana republic. He was condemning himself. He was the Treasurer. He was most unapologetic when Labor were in power and he appeared on television saying: âI would say it again because this country needs a wake-up call. You cannot continue to run a country with a current account deficit of $15,000 million a year.â That is what the former Prime Minister and Treasurer said.

The current Prime Minister, who was also Treasurer for a number of years, so he knows a lot about Treasury, reminded Mr Keating back in 1993âwhen he made a statement during a Perth radio interviewâthat we were going to be a banana republic when the current account deficit was $15,000 million and said: âIt is now $26,000 million. What are you going to do about it, Mr Keating?â Quite rightly so. The Prime Minister observed that this is the problem above all elseâit is the overwhelming problem. Those are the words used by the Prime Minister in the Perth radio interview. The Prime Minister was right. The former Prime Minister, Mr Keating, was right. But it is now not a $15,000 million banana republic statement; it not a $26,000 million overwhelming problem statement by Mr Howard. The figure is now $61,000 million.Â And why? Because our manufacturing industry have simply ceased to exist. Their situation is actually worse than that of agriculture.

I do not have the time, nor do I have the intention, to do the necessary research, but I do not think anyone would question for a moment that the situation of manufacturing is infinitely more hopeless than that of agriculture. Mr Vaile is a very nice and decent man. I think he tries to do the right thingâand I think everyone here would agree with thatâbut the Minister for Trade will go down in the history books as the minister that introduced the free trade agreement with the United States. Minister, do you seriously believe that our motor vehicle production plants, supplying to a market of 20 million people, are going to compete favourably against the Americans? That place is supplying a market of 400 million people and they are all moving to the border down Mexico way where they can get people to work for nothing.

The cattle industry, a giant industry that I have the pleasure of representing the major part of in Australia, is in fact a secondary industry. I was speaking to the principal of one of the biggest beef producers in Australia and he said, âDo you know where all the meat processing is?â I said, âYep, right in the centre of the United States, in Kansas City and Omaha.â He said, âNo, no, itâs moved.â I said, âDonât tell meâdown south?â He said, âYes, itâs all on the Mexican border now,â where they can access people who work for virtually nothingâthe Mexican wetbacks who come across the border.

So our situation is really desperate. Do you think you can just get in there and keep rolling up debt indefinitely? No. At some stage the banks will say, âYou canât have any more money.â We have the lowest savings level in Australian history; at the present moment Australia has negative savings. For the first time in our history, the average Australian is spending more money than he is earning, dramatically so. We are one of the very few countries on earth in that invidious situation.

Let me be very specific about how you turn this around. I am holding up a document here. I am on the natural resources committeeâthe House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry and Resourcesâand we were handed this document prepared by ABARE and Geoscience Australia, which is the old Bureau of Mineral Resources. This document shows a graph of petrol consumption and of petrol production in this countryâoil, if you like. The graph shows the levels to be about the same up to about 2002-03; it looks to be the same graph. But from then on they rapidly divide, with demand increasing and production decreasing dramatically, so that by 2009 more than half of this nationâs oil will have to come from overseas. By 2020, almost all of this nationâs oil will have to come from overseas.

The Americans are moving. They have closed down all of their marginal oilwells and they maintain a reserve in those marginal oilwells that can be opened in times of emergency. The US Senate has passed legislation to introduce what is effectively a 10 per cent ethanol blend in oil in the United States. They are already moving on this in a number of states, including New York and Californiaâand if people think this is some sort of sneaky way of helping their farmers, there is no grain or sugar cane in New York State or in the state of California. Neither of them broadacre farm, yet they are the great consumers. America is projected this year to be on three per cent ethanol.

This country, which is absolutely screaming out for an ethanol initiative, is on nil. All we get from the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, the Leader of the National Party, is: âIâm opposed to mandating, but Iâm going to give you all of these great handouts if you want to go and build a plant.â No-one is going to build a plant. There has not been one single action taken in Australia to build a plant, in spite of all the government incentives. But you cannot build a plant to sell petrol to people who will not buy itâand people will not buy it because the people who own the bowsers are the oil companies. They make an awful lot of money. They do not buy their oil at spot prices. They buy their oil at wellhead prices from wellheads that they in the main own. When we moved from wellhead pricing in Australia the price went from 3c a litre to about 10c a litre. When Doug Anthony lifted it, I thought it was a good move. But I was wrong and Doug Anthony was wrongâone of the very few times that he was wrong. I backed him strongly because I thought it was a good idea, but it was a very bad idea because the world price, the spot price, is infinitely higher than the price of production at the wellhead, which is what Shell, Mobil, Exxon and all these companies produce for. Here is an industry that was 10 per cent dieselâthere is $3,000 million, so five per cent of your problems have been overcome in one hit. You have only to do another 19 things of that size and you will have solved our problem in Australia. We will be making money instead of losing money.

The answers are there. But what are we doing instead of opening up our great resources that God has given us? The Good Book talks about talents. It talks about the man who had five talents and went out and traded and got his master another five talents, and it talks about the bloke who had two talents and got his master another two. The Lord said to each of them, âGood and faithful servant, come into your rich reward.â And there was a bloke who was given one talent, and he went and hid it under rock because he thought he might lose it. Mr Deputy Speaker, the vast resources of water that this nation has are in the Gulf of Carpentaria, which the Australian people have given me the privilege to represent. Over a third of Australiaâs water is in the Gulf of Carpentaria but, as I speak, the brainless government of Queensland is passing legislation to ban the usage of any of that water. If that is not a classic case of burying the talent under a rock because it might get lost I do not know what is.

The Gulf Country by itself can support a population of 100 million. You have a thousand kilometres of rolling black soilâand what is it doing? Seven million hectares of it has been taken over by the dirty, filthy Acacia nilotica tree that some bird has brought in from Asia or somewhere else. These are not my figures; they are figures from the agriculture department of Queensland. That land is disintegrating right now. We have not looked after it. We have not hidden it under a rock. It is falling to piecesâand though it is falling to pieces we are going to keep it the way it is.

Sometimes I think we go out of our way to antagonise Indonesia, our nearest neighbour. It seems that we just do thing after thing to antagonise our nearest neighbour. We should be friends with our neighbours but we should have good fences. Good fences make good neighbours, which is an old saying from the country I come from, and a very true saying. In another place we are debating about those fences at the present moment. One hundred million people in Indonesia go to bed hungry every night. Do you think it is a fair world when we sit on those resources and say that no-one is allowed to touch them, when we say that no graziers are allowed to take a single litre of that water out of those giant rivers? People say that it upsets the balance of nature. You can build all the dams you like but you will not be able to stop the flow of those giant rivers during our three-month wet season. Later in the year, again, you can build all the dams you like but you will never be able to make them run all year round. They are dry beds at the start of the year and they are huge rivers in the wet season.

We plead with this government to realise that you cannot get coal out of this country in a multiuser facility when you are saying, âIt should be a matter for the market to look after.â The market has had its chance at Dalrymple Bay and there are 52 ships going around in circles. I represent the greatest mineral province on earth, with $4,000 million or $5,000 million worth of minerals coming out of it. Up until about seven or eight years ago we processed all of those minerals. Half of the value is in processing and we processed those minerals. Three of our latest mines are Indian companies and they are exporting minerals as concentratesâthey are not processing them at all. The zinc refinery in Townsville have said on numerous occasions that they want to double production but they cannot.

Why are we suddenly sending all our stuff out? Because we have a national competition policy, that is why. There is no-one to build a baseload power station to provide us with the power to process it. The Treasurer says that if the project wants it, the project will build it. But we are talking about 10, 12, 20, 30 projects here. If that argument were used, there would be no coal industry in Queensland. And guess what the Australian economy is riding on? Something like 20 per cent of its income this year is coal. It would not be there if the government had not gone and built the infrastructure. There was not a single coalmine to feed Gladstone, not oneâUtah said it was going to build one at Blackwater. It is a similar case in Western Australia with the iron ore. So two of the countryâs biggest export earning items would not be there today if we applied the principles of national competition policy.
