Thousands of millions of dollars from my electorate are being lost now because metals are going out unprocessed because we do not have a baseload power station. Under national competition policy we cannot have a baseload power stationâit will never happen. So, please, will the government realise that the country is going broke. It screams out for action and there is no action coming. Infrastructure must be supplied to enable us to grow. That is the great lesson of history for Australia. The wheat industry came out of silos built by the Theodore government in Queensland. The sugar industry came out of sugar mills built by the government in Queensland. The coal industry came out of the infrastructureâthe ports and railway linesâbuilt by the government in Queensland. Who runs them afterwards is not important, but the risk up front when you have a multiuser facility must be taken by government. (Time expired)

talker.name: Stone, Dr Sharman, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration
talker.name: Dr STONE

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI wish to address the Main Committee again to close the second reading debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2005-2006 and the cognate bills: Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 2005-2006, Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 1) 2005-2006, Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 2004-2005 and Appropriation Bill (No. 6) 2004-2005. I am pleased to bring what has been a lively and extensive budget debate to a close. Once again there has been broad participation in the debate, with more than 65 members contributing. This demonstrates the parliamentâs ongoing keen interest in the governmentâs management of the economy and its strategies for the future. The public can be reassured that due consideration is being given to the needs of individuals and the broader Australian community in this great parliamentary forum that we have.

speech.para: I would like to thank all those members who have contributed to the debate. The discussion has focused on a broad range of issues, from the general state of the economy to issues emerging in membersâ electorates, specific funding proposals and the oppositionâs suggestion that the government has somehow failed to provide for the delivery of important services. Of course, we are all interested in what the opposition speakers have had to say about these bills and the broader budget but, not surprisingly, I and my colleagues in government do not agree with most of the oppositionâs sentiments. That is what they have to do in opposition.

I would like to take this opportunity to once again provide an overview of the package of appropriation bills. I will start with the budget bills. These bills provide for substantial funding totalling approximately $55.3 billion. They reflect the governmentâs broad objective to maintain a strong economy and are framed for the future, in particular the future opportunities of our young people, the future care of our aged, the future health services needs and demands of our citizens, the security of our nation and the future growth of the Australian economy.

The initiatives provided in the budget bills include funding of $45 billion for health and aged care, $5 billion investment through vocational education and training agreements, $12 billion commitment to transport infrastructure between 2004-05 and 2008-09, abolition of the three per cent tariff on imported business inputs, cuts to personal income tax worth $21.7 billion over four years and $522 million for national security. In addition to these initiatives, the budget bills provide record levels of funding to ensure that the Australian community has access to child care, education and training opportunities and that carers are recognised for their efforts. This is consistent with the priority the government places on these fundamental support services.

Also included in the package of five appropriation bills are two supplementary additional estimates bills for this financial year, 2004-05. These bills propose expenditure of $314.3 million for important initiatives that can be accommodated this financial year because of the strength of our fiscal position and the Australian economy generally. The funding in the supplementary additional estimates bills provides, amongst other things: $160 million for transitional grants to compensate eligible entities for loss of access to a fringe benefits tax exemption; $28 million and $17.3 million from appropriation bills Nos 5 and 6 respectively for expenses associated with the Australian Defence Force deployment in Iraq; $23 million for Australiaâs increased financial contributions to the United Nationâs peacekeeping operations; and $4 million to reimburse the states for the cost of providing medical teams under the AUSASSIST arrangements during the tsunami relief effort. I wish to emphasise that the significant level of expenditure proposed in the package of bills is only possible because of the governmentâs continued strong management of the economy.

Let me talk about our emphasis on the future. The members for Swan and Lilley commented on the Future Fund. Through the Future Fund the government will accumulate and quarantine assets now to meet future superannuation benefit payments that its employees are entitled to. This will free up resources from the budget at a time when growing demographic pressures in areas like health and aged care spending are expected to emerge. The superannuation entitlements of Australian government employees, which include defence personnel and members of parliament as well as public servants, are part of the costs of providing government services. The Future Fund will enhance intergenerational equity by ensuring that the current generation of taxpayers meet their share of these costs rather than adding to the burden of future generations.

Through its commitment to sound financial management, the government has put the budget in surplus, making funds available to retire debt and now, through the Future Fund, to commence savings for its future obligations. The government will make transfers to this fund from realised cash surpluses and other financial assets, as it is able to do so given its spending priorities. The government will reinvest fund earnings, demonstrating its commitment to growing the fund. The Future Fund will be a financial asset fund that will not invest directly in infrastructure; the governmentâs investment mandate will allow the fund to invest in infrastructure trusts in companies that build and manage infrastructure and in property trusts. In this way, the government can ensure that the Future Fund can invest in infrastructure projects with a strong business case and the ability to produce commercial returns.

The establishment of the Future Fund will increase the pool of funds available for investment in the Australian economy, and the more vibrant economy will benefit all Australians. If the government is looking to invest in infrastructure that has broader economic and community benefits, such as roads, the appropriate source of funding is general revenue, not the Future Fund. For instance, our record spending on roads through Auslink is funded from the budget.

At the commencement of the debate, the honourable member for Lilley moved an amendment to the second reading motion on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2005-2006. The government does not support the proposed amendment. The reasons for this should be clear. I have already addressed many of the specific issues that we are funding and that were raised in the amendment. I record my disappointment at the cynicism expressed in the proposed amendment. The budget bills and the supplementary additional estimates bills proposed by the government support reforms that are required to address the significant changes currently faced by the Australian economy. Only through these reforms can we ensure that the economy will continue to grow to its maximum potential.

I also emphasise that the government is not spending money that it does not have. The substantial expenditure provided for in these bills is a dividend of the governmentâs strong and responsible management of the Australian economy and fiscal policy.

In conclusion, the three budget bills for 2005-06 and the two supplementary additional estimates bills for 2004-05 are important pieces of legislation underpinning the governmentâs activities and reforms to be introduced over the next 12 months or so. I commend the budget bills and the supplementary additional estimates to the House.

talk.start.para: âI have a question for the Parliamentary Secretary for Children and Youth Affairs which relates to the Family and Community Services portfolio and the measures that the Department of Family and Community Services uses for unmet demand for child care. Could you give us some information identifying the various measures used by the Department of Family and Community Services to identify unmet needâwhether the department uses the measure of the number of places requested by services or the number of children on waiting lists or some other source? Could you describe the methodology used by the department and specify whether different measures are used for different types of child care?
(Hon. BK Bishop)âThe parliamentary secretary can choose to answer now or make notes and answer a little later.
âI will answer later.
âI will not use the whole of the five minutes each time but I do have a number of questions.
âAre there other members wishing to ask questions?

âThe member for Shortland also wishes to ask questions. Could the parliamentary secretary tell us how often unmet demand is measured by the Department of Family and Community Services? We hear a great deal of anecdotal evidence about unmet demand in child care. We have been told that anecdotal evidence is not satisfactory in this area. However, without knowing the measures that the Department of Family and Community Services uses it is impossible for us to use other measures. In deciding to allocate in this budget 84,300 places to out of school hours care and 1,500 to family day care, how were those figures arrived at? Could the parliamentary secretary tell us whether there has been a measurement of the unmet demand in out of school hours care and family day care by the Department of Family and Community Services and whether the figures arrived at, which were included in the budget, relate to some calculation done by the Department of Family and Community Services?

âI wish to use this opportunity to highlight what appears to be a significant campaign being run by the St Vincent de Paul Society in its efforts to respond to some of the governmentâs policy around family and community services. Anthony Dalton commented in the Australian on 13 June that we have in this country a system where no money means no access. That is an affront to the work that is done in community services in this country. I use this opportunity to highlight a long campaignâand certainly a very active media adviser scurrying between media outlets around this countryâto sell a line that is far from the reality of community services in this country.

speech.para: We saw this begin as far back as 11 June with an editorial in the Weekend Australian which referred to the St Vincent de Paul Societyâs âSeinfeld stoushâan argument over nothingâ and said:

quote.para: The societyâs is a sad statement, but not for the reasons its researchers think. It demonstrates why welfare lobbyists should abandon assumptions that more public money can save people from being poor.

speech.para: Following on from that editorial was a piece on the radio by Terry McCarthy and then a piece by John Wicks in the Age and thenâand this does disappoint meâthe Australian actually printed, reprinted and reprinted again the same old story with the same old figures. I have taken the liberty of highlighting the repetition unfortunately running through this major daily of the same information appearing in a different part of the newspaper each week. The usual suspects appear to be John Fowles, Terry McCarthy, Anthony Dalton and then Gavin Duffyâon the bottom of the press releaseâwho are simply running the same line. Let us see what it is, and it is not a new one.

As long as there have been welfare economics and tax policy there has been an argument about whether we have a âmoreâ or âlessâ progressive tax policy. In family and community service there is the argument about whether we can increase levels of welfare to those that need it the most. No matter how much evidence is provided that is in fact what is happening with our current family and community policy, we see a continual attack using tax policy as an excuse to criticise what is happening in family and community services. What we need in this debate, as we have already seen, is some coherent, rational and considered argument. When an organisation like the St Vincent de Paul Society, with their clearly described mission, begin to take a policy approach to criticising family and community service policy in this country by having a shot at tax policy, they move themselves away from what they should be doing, which is sticking to their mission. It is not a complex one; it is, in fact, not a very detailed one. It is quite simple: it is to deepen the Catholic faith of its members, to heighten the awareness of Jesus Christ and, of course, to help those in most need to take control of their destiny.

talk.start.para: âI want to seek your clarification, Madam Deputy Speaker.
(Hon. BK Bishop)âIs this a point of order?
âIt is a point of order.
âWhat is the point of order?
âI asked a question of the parliamentary secretary and I was expecting an answer. I was just wondering about it.

âThere is no point of order but, to the point of clarification, the parliamentary secretary may answer at the end of the period of interventions. The member for Bowman is speaking. He has got five minutes and then you can be called.
âI would have expected the parliamentary secretaryâ
âShe is not obliged to at this stage. She can when she chooses.
ânot to answer but to indicate that she was answering afterwards, if that was the case, and that she would get back to me later.
âShe already indicated that to you.

âNo, she indicated on the first question but not on the subsequent question. She was consulting her bureaucrats and I was expecting an indication that, if she was not prepared to answer the question now, she would come back to us later with an answer.

âMadam Deputy Speaker, on indulgence: it might assist the good order of the chamber if the Clerk was to guide us a little in this. My understanding of consideration in detail, and we only see this once a year, is that a member gives an address of up to five minutes and then the minister or the parliamentary secretary responds to that. With great respect to the member for Sydney, I think she is trying to use a Senate estimates type arrangement in this chamber. It might assist the second chamber if we could have an explanation of the most suitable way to do this thing.

âI thank the member for his point on indulgence but I point out that the member for Sydney is entitled to ask questions in her intervention in consideration in detail and that the parliamentary secretary may address those questions as she sees fit and at a time she sees fit, when the interventions are concluded, if that is the time she wishes to do it, or if she wishes to intervene earlier she may do so. The member for Bowman had the call, but his time has elapsed because of this, so I will call the member for Sydney and then the member for Bowman will be invited to speak again.

âThank you, Madam Acting Deputy Speaker. I will just ask my questions in a much more longwinded fashion then, shall I? I asked the parliamentary secretary about the data collected by the Department of Family and Community Services that was used to determine the number of places allocated to out of school hours care and to family day care in the most recent budget. The data collected by the Department of Family and Community Services that I hope the parliamentary secretary will get back to us with is mostly not made public by the Department of Family and Community Services. Every two years there is what is called the Census of Child Care Services, and we are still waiting on the results of the 2004 child-care census. I hope those figures will be released some time in 2005, although at this stage it looks as though it is more likely to be 2006, which is when the next census data will be collected.

speech.para: The data collected by the Department of Family and Community Services would be incredibly useful to private child-care operators who are considering setting up child care in areas where they are not sure of what the Department of Family and Community Services estimates will be in relation to the demand into the future. What I would like to hear from the parliamentary secretary is when the information that the Department of Family and Community Services uses, presumably to have an input on the number of out of school hours care places or the number of family day care places that are required, will be made public. How can we be certain that private sector child-care operators who are risking a great deal of money to set up child-care centresâbetween $1 million and $2 million for a centreâcan have access to that information on an equal basis?

Child-care operators, in the long day care sector in particular, tell me they are concerned that some child-care operators do have access to this information. They believe that it is an unfair competitive advantage if people do have information about likely demand into the future. I would like the parliamentary secretary to tell us: is any of the information collected about undersupply and oversupply made public? Is it likely to be made public in the near future? Can she give us a guarantee that there is no unequal access, by some operators compared with other operators, to information that the Department of Family and Community Services collects in order to make its own assessments about need in this area?

talk.start.para: âI will continue with my analysis of what has become over the last month or so a de facto media campaign. I draw attention both to radio interviews by Terry McCarthy and to a series of articles in the Age and the Australian on 30 May. What I felt was quite incisive was the 8 June press release that referred to some statements by the CIS and suggested that the CIS should âtake a Bex and have a good lie downâ.

speech.para: Running in predominantly the Australian newspaper we are seeing the St Vincent de Paul Society engaging in this perennial debate about progressiveness of tax relief. In essence, I think they are confusing the fact that we have welfare policy and tax policy, and they are taking the chance to attack tax policy in the hope that that might in some way improve the lot of those who are on low incomes. What they do not tell us, of course, is that when it comes to payment of tax as a share of the total net amount, the lowest decile of Australians are payingâand I apologise that these are the next to most recent figuresâonly 0.7 per cent of the total tax bill. So tax policy is not a terribly effective way of addressing poverty, particularly in the areas where St Vincent de Paul is working.

Even if we take the bottom 20 per cent of Australians, you are still dealing with 2.3 per cent, and once again these are figures from late last decade. That is an incredibly tiny proportion of tax that is paid by that fraction of Australians. I do not have a problem with that as an amount. My question is that if you really want to address the needs of those who live particularly in the desperate poverty with which St Vincent de Paul works then we have to be looking at areas of welfare to improve that. That does not mean that your job is to keep people on welfare. It does not mean that you need to have a deep ideological hostility to providing people with opportunity.

The mission of St Vincent de Paul is to help their clients to take control of their destinies. Can you see a better way of doing that than by providing a strong economy with opportunities, like an opportunity for a job? That is an opportunity that we are seeing right now in OECD figures and comparisons, but one that seems to be being ignored in what I see from St Vincent de Paul as a de facto political campaign in making a criticism of coalition policy at the moment without any valid comparison of alternatives, without providing any form of alternative vision and certainly without providing a comparison with what happened 10 years ago and the lot of the poor in the period 1983 to 1996?

If we are going to be returning tax in the form of a tax break, I believe it stands to reason to do it progressively. If we are seeing higher income earners paying a larger proportion of tax, then it also stands to reason that they will get more of a tax break than those who have paid lower amounts. Once again, we have seen St Vincent de Paul fluctuating or even oscillating in relative comparisons, talking about their position relative to other Australians, and then taking absolute figures and talking about $6 or $200. I think that demeans the debate. I think they are taking one side, and a predominantly envy based approach at times, but more importantly they move into the sphere of taking a political view. There is nothing wrong with anyone having a political view. My problem is that when that academic, and sometimes intellectual, posturing is being done you have to be willing to step into the ring and engage in political debate, but not then pop your glasses on and say, âBut donât hit me back because Iâm doing important work in the non-profit sectorâ. They have to be one or the other.

There is a certain intellectual debate in talking about the progressiveness of tax policy: how we collect it, use it and refund it. There is perhaps some limited value in a moral and ethical discourse about tax policy and welfare policy, but I do not think they do themselves any service whatsoever. In fact, there is really no value at all in having them running around the major dailies presenting their selected figures and then criticising other people for simply using other selected figures.Â

I refer to an interview with Terry McCarthy where he says that the current debate on NATSEM research that we have been having for some years now, and in particular referring to the Prime Minister, is making:

quote.para: â¦ a spurious assertion that the poor in Australia are growing rich at a faster rate than the rich are.
Now, we would have to sayâ
here at St Vincent de Paulâ
that thatâs just a cruel hoax on the whole millions of Australians, because the simple fact that in absolute terms this is not true.

speech.para: On the one hand, there is a criticism that there is selective use of statistics by the CIS and by NATSEM and then, Vinnies, we simply have another set of selected figures being used in retaliation. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI find it rather amazing that here we are in consideration in detail and a member of the government is verballing St Vincent de Paul, saying that their sole and only role is to administer in a religious fashion. I can say to the member for Bowman opposite that St Vincent de Paul play a very vital role within the community that I represent. They look after the people that are disadvantaged by this government. They look after the people who are done over by the policies that are introduced into this House by you and your colleagues. They provide a vital service to the most disadvantaged people in the community. The social research that has been conducted by St Vincent de Paul over the years has been invaluable. On many occasions I have used it as the basis for assisting people within the community that I represent. I know that my colleagues on this side of the House value the work of St Vincent de Paul and, in addition to that, value the research that they do. We do not have to turn our minds back too far to remember when the government was trying to quieten charitable organisations by refusing to fund them properly if they spoke out and made political comment on issues like this. I find it absolutely appalling and disgraceful to hear in consideration in detail a member of the government rip into St Vincent de Paul the way the member for Bowman has.

speech.para: I will turn very quickly to another issue, an area in which I think the government has been quite deficient in this budget. I congratulate the government on introducing the carers paymentâthe payment of $1,000 and $600 to people who are in receipt of the carers payment and the carers allowance. The measure was greatly welcomed by these people. I must say, though, that I believe there is a better way to deliver these payments and services to people. It should be on a more ongoing basis rather than an ad hoc, one-off approach. One group that has missed out and been ignored by the government is the partners of veterans. Women who look after a partner who is on the veterans disability pensionâthese are the partners of disabled veteransâhave been deemed by the government to be unworthy of receiving the same bonus as the partners of other people who are on the disability support pension.

I know that many of these carers are eligible for carers allowance but they have been denied the $1,000 carers payment; they will get the $600 carers allowance. Their veteran partner is on the veterans disability pension but, unlike someone else whose partner is in receipt of a disability support pension, they miss out on the $1,000. Some of these partners of veterans live horrendous lives. They provide the strongest support that anyone can give, and I believe the government has slapped them in the face by ignoring and forgetting them. I call on the government to revisit the carers payment and to look at introducing a bonus of $1,000 to the partners of veteransâpeople who are in receipt of carers allowance but not in receipt of carers payment because they are the partner of a disabled veteran.

talk.start.para: â I had not intended to enter discussions at the consideration in detail stage except I wish to make a few points. Firstly, my colleague who spoke earlier was not launching an attack on St Vincent de Paul. I for one have a strong and abiding respect for St Vincent de Paul and the work they do. I know the work they do in my own community, especially in Bundaberg. They run a menâs shelter and two different shops that I am aware of. They do marvellous work in caring for people in the community and I like to see them supported with government grants for that work. I think the point that the previous speaker was making was that when any organisationâbe it St Vincent de Paul, Blue Care, Anglicare or any of those organisationsâsteps into the policy area the government has a right to answer that point of view. That is not to in any way impugn the reputation of St Vincent de Paul but to put the governmentâs case.

speech.para: If you take the recent budget in isolation and say, âAll these concessions have favoured the high-income earners,â you possibly need to look at that continuum since 1969. Let us take the lower end of the category, the one that my friend the member for Shortland just referred to. If you consider the continuum of tax cuts, you will find that even since the year 2000 people on the basic wage have had their tax reduced from 20 per cent to 17 per cent and to 15 per cent. So they are now paying 15c in the dollar. Not only that but the disregarded amount has been raised from $5,400 to $6,000 andâcorrect me if I am wrongâthat lower tax scale now applies up to $21,600. There has been a considerable reduction in taxation for the basic income earner. In addition, there has been an increase in the family tax benefit A and B. If you take that in net terms against the net financial position of low-income earners, many of them are paying no net tax at all. If you are going to have this debate, you have to put it into the context of the various factors that are affecting it. Fifteen cents in the dollar must be one of the lowest tax rates in the world for low-income earners.

I make another point, and it is in the wider context of what we were talking about before, in the general welfare policy area. If I read the budget papers right, we are now spending 61 per cent of the national income on health, aged care and welfare. By any standardsâand I think one of the replies to the St Vincent de Paul article made this pointâAustraliaâs care in that area is second to none in the world. By all means let us have this debate and flesh out areas of weaknessâthe government is not perfect; it makes mistakes like everyone elseâbut let us not have a carping debate that just finds a lot of little titbits and says that this is a general reflection on the care of lower income earners. Clearly it is not. The governmentâs care of lower income earners is equal to, if not better than, the previous government. I do not say that in the context of us and you but, rather, to let us have a more mature debate on how we might do a better job for these people and then let the parliamentary secretary respond to that.

talk.start.para: âI want to raise the question of housing in the context of this portfolioâs estimates. If there is an area of criticismâand I hope that the honourable member for Hinkler would not think that it is just carpingâI think that housing is an area where this government, at the federal level, has tended to say, âNo, it is a state responsibility; we do not want to get involved.â Shelter is very important to Australians, especially those who are on lower incomes. There can be no sector of Australian society where it is more important than it is for Indigenous Australians. In any inquiry, whether it is on Indigenous health or Indigenous education, a holistic approach has to be taken to enable and ensure that Indigenous Australians are able to fulfil the capacities that they have. And shelter is one of those areas.

speech.para: Regrettably, over time both sides of politics have made mistakes, but there is a tendency to blame the Indigenous communities themselves. The Indigenous communities say, âGive us the support, give us the environment, that enables us to go forward; give us a say in the type of housing that we want to see put in place.â Thank goodness the days of inappropriate housing design in eastern capital cities that went into the Northern Territory and the far-flung areas of this continent are over, but there should be more authority given to, and more activity in the decision making of, Indigenous communities to put in place appropriate housing for those communities.

If I look at an electorate like mine where there is high private dwelling ownershipâpeople either buying or owning outrightâeven though it seems to be a small sector of the shelter that is provided to the community that I represent, one of the things that is neglected is access to rental accommodation. There are issues in the private market that go against the ability of low-income earners to be able to go into the private market. There is a role for public and community housing and there are certain reasons why I believe that the federal government should take a greater role in partnership with the state.

One of the great crises to confront my local communities is that new arrivals through the refugee and humanitarian program are coming into our communities and because they have no credit reference behind themâin fact the whole culture is alien to them in the relationshipâthey miss out on access to the private market. We need to ensure that support is given to community efforts to ensure that shelter is put in place that is accessible to refugees and people coming in under the humanitarian program. That is at least one area where I implore the government to ensure that it works to a greater extent with their state colleagues.

talk.start.para: âMadam Deputy Speaker, I appreciate your indulgence in explaining how the consideration in detail phase of this debate works. I am obviously new to it myself and, as the member for Hinkler reminds us, it only happens once a year. I will endeavour to address some of the points raised by members opposite. Unfortunately, I need to say to the member for Sydney that in response to her question about the data collected and used to determine out of school hours placesâshe asked about the unmet demand for child care, how we as a government calculate that, how the department calculates it and how often it is measuredâI am unable to go into that level of detail here. I felt that that was a bit of a Senate estimates process question and was surprised to hear it. I am not aware of any unequal access to child-care data amongst providers. Obviously in a marketplace there is speculation and rumour but I do not believe that you can trace any of that to information that is released by the department. The department acts in an accountable way in these things and whatever principles of corporate governance apply to the private sector would apply similarly to the public sector in dealing with this information.

speech.para: I would also like to mention that the number of outside school hours places offered in the budget is 84,300. Family day care places were increased by 2,500, in-home care places were increased by 1,000, and the government is providing an extra 52,000 low-income families with additional assistance for the cost of child care. It is true that in making choices as families, child care is an important option and opportunity that needs to be made available and we as a government are doing that.

The member for Shortland, if I can move to her pointâand she has now left the chamberâdealt with the carer bonuses announced in the budget. Recipients of carers payment receive an ex gratia payment of $1,000 and carers allowance of $600. They have the carers payment and the carers allowance around the wrong way there, but those were tax-free payments which followed on from the previous undertaking last year. It is the second time we have made such payments. The member for Shortland speaks up for the veterans in her community, as she has on other occasions in the House, and I commend her for her commitment to the veterans that she represents.

However, the governmentâs decision to provide the carer bonus is directed and targeted at those persons who qualify for both carer payment and carer allowance. These are people who have limited income and who require constant care and daily care and attention. That is a factor that the legislation highlights and I think that the member for Shortland mentioned that in her remarks as well. For us to say that those requirements of limited income and constant daily care and attention apply to the veteran community as a whole is obviously not the case. The Department of Veteransâ Affairs looks after and cares for our veterans very well I think. I am sure the member for Shortland will appreciate the point that I am making, that you cannot group veterans as a whole into specific targeted areas of people who would require daily constant care and attention and therefore would be targeted for these precise payments of carer payment and carer allowance.

I believe that the member for Hinkler has addressed the issue of the debate surrounding St Vincent de Paul. I want to place on record, as parliamentary secretary dealing in avenues of children at risk and youth homelessness, that I do appreciate the work that St Vincent de Paul does. We all know of the programs in our own electorates and the good work that they carry out in the community. But, like the member for Bowman and the member for Hinkler, I have been a little disappointed at the overtly political stand that I have seen some members of the organisationâI do not think this covers allâtake in the current debate.

The centrepiece of this budget and the issue that it hinges on is the Welfare to Work policy of this government. I do not feel that there is any better illustration of the need for the government to take serious Welfare to Work measures than an article attributed to todayâs Sydney Morning Herald. The article concerned 30-year-old Sevasti Kelepesis and her three children. Her life came to a shattering halt four years ago when her husband died in a motorbike crash, metres from her home. She describes the experience as a living death and she describes how it affected her children. She had married at 19, she had done a dressmaking course, she had stayed home to have children, she had no skills and she was facing a time of serious emotional agony. I will continue my remarks shortly.

talk.start.para: âIn this consideration in detail debate I want to ask some questions of the parliamentary secretary about the Daylesford multifunctional child-care centre in my electorate. That centre is the only child-care centre in Hepburn Shire and it provides occasional care, family day care, long day care and out of school hours care all from the one site. As part of the broadband review, the government has determined that this centre no longer quite fits the guidelines. In fact, it has been told that, unless it becomes either a long day care centre or an occasional place child-care centre, it cannot operate in any other way. If it does either of those things, the best case scenario is that it is facing a cut of $87,000, as well as losing out of school hours care places. It would no longer be able to provide that service and it would have to increase its fees in order to continue operating.

speech.para: There has been a fair bit of media attention about this. I think the Melbourne Age did a very good piece outlining the concerns of parents, but we have now seen the government defer its decision on what it is going to do with this child-care centre for three months. I specifically want to ask the parliamentary secretary what the department is proposing to do in the three months. What information do you currently not have that you will have in three months time to enable you to make a decision about what to do with the funding of this centre? I would also like to know whether there are any other centres which have been part of the broadband review, not just multifunctional centres, that have had this decision deferred for three months and why. I would also like to know whether you intend, as part of that review, to consider reversing the decision.

talk.start.para: âThe matter of public housing that was raised by the Deputy Speaker and the member for Scullin when he was in the chamber is, I think, an important one. I for one would take on board his appeal that the Commonwealth gets more involved, but what I have found, in the debates that I have in my own area with the state minister Rob Schwarten, who is the member for Rockhampton, is that he totally denies the amount of money that has gone into rental support. That is a very important component of the governmentâs agenda. You can argue of course that if that money had all gone into public housing then we would have a lot more housing commission homes and high-rise properties, as we have seen in Melbourne, with their own inherent social problems.

speech.para: What is important with public housing is to get a balance between high-rise, cluster developments and individual houses, and we should not see people in welfare housing put out on the edge of town in a distant suburb where there is no transport. There has to be a strategy to put welfare housing in among other housing. People should enjoy the same access to transport and civic services. We should never go back to the suburbs around Australia which became notorious in their day, although, I must admit, in recent years they have developed new imagesâElizabeth in Adelaide and Inala in Brisbane where welfare housing was done to such an extent that that became the image of the district.

We also need to recognise in QueenslandâI can speak only for the Queensland experienceâthat, while the Commonwealth component of welfare housing has been increasing, the proportionate amount of state housing has been decreasing. You really have to ask yourself whether the states are fair dinkum in their attack on the Commonwealth if they themselves are not prepared to at least match in percentage terms the Commonwealth contribution. I too am a great supporter of SAAP schemes because they provide housing for the most seriously disadvantaged. Again, Queensland for many years not only did not increase their contribution in line with the Commonwealth; worse than that, they capped the amount of housing going into that particular field. That is regrettable because there is a whole range of housing measures: the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, where there is a direct contribution from the Commonwealth to low-cost housing; the Commonwealth contribution through the rent assistance schemeâand I cannot remember the dollars but in Queensland it is something like $540 million a year; the SAAP scheme; and in some states the Commonwealth cooperates with local authorities to provide retirement units. When you take the whole range of those housing measures, you get a more holistic picture of welfare housing. I know the member for Ballarat is passionate about welfare housing and in no way do I criticise her, but let us look at the holistic picture and not just at one narrow segment.

talk.start.para: âI have just heard the Parliamentary Secretary for Children and Youth Affairs say that part of the main agenda for this budget was Welfare to Work. Given that this budget will tighten the conditions for people gaining disability pensions, I would be very interested to know what the government will be doing. Will they be introducing any programs to make sure that people with disabilities are employed by Commonwealth departments? In my electorate, which has the second-highest take-up of disability pensions in the state, the Commonwealth employ only about 50 people. I would hope that they match their words with some actions to assist the employment of people with disabilities in their own departments.

âI will move to the remarks made by the member for Newcastle in a moment, but I want to finish my previous remarks. Yes, Welfare to Work is a centrepiece of the budget. I was talking about 30-year-old Sevasti KelepesisâI apologise for mispronouncing her name. I made the point that after a disastrous accident in which she lost her husband, this young woman was home with three small children, her husband having been the breadwinner. He had worked in the building industry and the family had depended totally on him. She was left surviving on the pension and child benefit. After 18 months of struggle, she wanted to start afresh, so she contacted Centrelink. She said: âIt changed my life. I joined their Jobs, Education and Training programâârecently moved from the Department of Family and Community Services to the Department of Employment and Workplace Relationsââthat assists customers in removing barriers in returning to work or study.â She said that she is completing her certificate II beauty course at Gymea TAFE and that she is going to pursue certificate III.

speech.para: So for many single mothers like the woman in this article retraining and re-entering the work force have brought confidence and hope. She says that she is beginning to enjoy life. That reminds me of something I have said to the member for Sydney before: you make a living by what you get, but you make a life by what you give. This is a perfect case study of that. This highlights the governmentâs Welfare to Work, and by enabling a woman like this to move from welfare to work we are making a real difference in her life. As she says, she has found happiness.

talk.start.para: âItâs our program.
âWe introduced it.

âI am delighted that we can agree on that. Can I address the issue of housing assistance, which was raised by the member for Scullin, I think. I remind members opposite that the government is committed to providing housing assistance. Through the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement we will provide $4.75 billion over five years, which commenced in July 2003. That is about $930 million each year. So the federal government is providing the states with funding, allowing the states to use it as they best see fit to target the appropriate people who need public housing. To say that is not happening is simply not correct.

speech.para: The member for Scullin also raised the issue of Indigenous housing in particular. I remind him that in the budget we released a new Indigenous housing package that encourages shared responsibility; it is the sum of $112.8 million. This is a package funded over four years which focuses on three key strategic initiatives. It continues a program of involving Indigenous households and communities in assessing and repairing up to 500 houses a year in about 15 communities. It will focus on encouraging the reform of Indigenous community housing through improved governance and asset and tenancy management practices. This government has also made a commitment to continue the delivery of the Army Aboriginal Community Assistance Program in at least one community a year, which is a positive demonstration of practical reconciliation. The package bolsters the joint federal and Territory governmentsâ efforts to improve the viability and sustainability of Indigenous community organisations and to improve the quality of Indigenous housing. So I hope that satisfactorily answers the questions of the member for Scullin, who is no longer in the chamber.

talk.start.para: (Hon. BK Bishop)âWe had an agreement that, at a quarter to five, we would move to the next area of budget expenditure, being the Communications, Information Technology and the Arts portfolio. But I think we should just continue on this portfolio a little longer before we move to the next portfolio, as there does still seem to be some interest here. There is only a question or two.

âI want to respond to put on the record that the parliamentary secretaryâs comments about the Jobs, Education and Training program are an excellent example of just what this government should be doing when it comes to moving people from welfare to work. It was an excellent program introduced by the last Labor government. But it has been consistently underspent by this government with $15 million a year allocated to Jobs, Education and Trainingâconsistently underspentâand in this very budget a limit has been put on the JET program so that if you are undertaking a course that lasts for more than a year you do not have access to JET. What an extraordinary situation! If you are undertaking training in an area of skills shortage, for exampleâif you are going to train to be a hairdresser or you want to train to be nurseâthen you are not going to have access to JET funding. Extraordinary!

speech.para: What Labor has consistently said about helping people move from welfare to work is that it is very important. We accept that most sole parents, most recipients of parenting payment, whether they are on their own or in a relationship, and most disability support pensioners would love to be in the work force if they could be. They would love to be in the work force if they had adequate education and training for the jobs that are out there and if they had adequate child care, and in the case of people on the disability support pension if they can find employers who are prepared to employ someone with a disability.

This government has turned away 20,000 young people from TAFE and 20,000 young people from university every year, and we are wondering why these young people are not moving into the work force. There are many sole parents, many people on parenting payment and many disability support pensioners whose dearest dream is to be in the work force. When this government helps them instead of blaming them for their situation, then I am sure we will see them moving into the work force.

talk.start.para: âWe need to move the debate on and I am keen to assist in that process, so I just want to make a couple of brief responses. The member for Newcastle talked about help for people moving off the disability support pension. I remind her of the $80 million prevocational participation account, which supports people with disabilities by providing services to make them job ready. That is a budget announcement specifically aimed at the people you have talked about. I say to the member for Sydney that I was not trying to play petty politics over whose program is whose; I was simply saying it demonstrates that when you get out of a life of welfare and into a life of work you find success and happiness in your contribution. You and I would both agree on that.
(Hon. BK Bishop)âThe question is that the proposed expenditure for the Family and Community Service Portfolio be agreed to.

speech.para: Question agreed to.
Communications, Information Technology and the Arts Portfolio
Proposed expenditure, $2,147,750,000.

talk.start.para: âThe 2005-06 budget appropriations for sport and associated recreation activities can only be described as a cobbled together mess. Setting aside the governmentâs assistance to athletes competing in the 2008 Beijing Olympics and money to assist with the staging of the 2006 Melbourne Commonwealth Games, the only initiative in this budget is the funding of a number of local sporting facilities. Even if a generous view is taken of the larger of these projects by ascribing some possible regional relevance to themâsuch as the works at Kogarah and Brookvale ovals in New South Wales, and Skilled Stadium and Whitten Oval in Victoriaâthe same cannot be said for the 16 projects funded in the seat of McEwen and the five projects funded in the seat of Makin. The McEwen and Makin projects are for minor capital works at local cricket clubs, football clubs and soccer clubs. These may well be worthwhile projects but, at best, they should be the responsibility of local communities and local governments, not the federal government. There can be no possible connection between the upgrade of facilities for the Macedon and Pooraka football clubs and a national sports facilities policy. When asked to explain how decisions to fund these facilities were made, the Minister for the Arts and Sport acknowledged there was no policy framework or strategic plan. He said:

quote.para: We make decisions on the basis of advice we receive from people in various electorates.

speech.para: Very selective electorates, it seems. When you add these funding decisions to those made last year as part of the Regional Partnerships program you have to ask why the government bothers to appoint a sports minister. Other ministers and even backbenchers clearly not only have the authority to make decisions on the funding of sports facilities but can invent a new sports facility funding program when they need it. This is all done with no apparent consultation with the sports minister. All this highlights is the lack of any policy work in the sports portfolio. The 2005-06 budget reflects the situation. There is no strategy for sport in the budget.

Elite athletes may feel they have been looked after, but even they should feel uneasy. Where is the strategic investment in developing the next generation of elite athletes? Where is the strategic investment in upgrading national sports facilities to ensure Australia remains competitive? The answer to both questions is that it is not there. There is no national sports development strategy. There is no national plan about anything to do with sport. The only national plan we can see in this budget is for the federal government to become involved in funding local sporting facilities at the whim of ministers, an approach that the Victorian sports minister Justin Madden has said is the opposite to the response received to previous requests for federal government assistance for the funding of sporting facilities. Minister Madden is reported as saying:

quote.para: Where state sports ministers have raised the issue about facilities funding, the Federal Government said look, they will only fund international and national facilities. Local facilities are for local communities to fund.

speech.para: The Prime Minister has also been a bit vague on the matter. His response to a journalistâs question about possible funding for a football stadium in Newcastle was:

quote.para: Well, Iâve had that proposition put to me, itâs not normally the role of a Federal Government to fund individual stadiums. But weâre considering it, I donât want to rule it out completely but itâs not the sort of thing that normally a Commonwealth Government does. But we have had a submission put to us and weâll consider it.

speech.para: We are still waiting to hear about that particular consideration. I wonder if the minister would like to respond.

talk.start.para: (Hon. BK Bishop)âThe minister is not obliged to respond at this stage if he does not wish to.

âI will turn to another issue, Madam Deputy Speaker. Even where there are important matters to be addressed, this budget ignores them. For example, the government received a report last year on the need for a new body to investigate allegations of doping in sport. Following receipt of the report, a discussion paper was produced by the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. In November last year the minister indicated in Senate estimates hearings that the government would announce a policy on this important matter as soon as possible. To this minister âas soon as possibleâ obviously does not mean this year as there is no mention of any funding for this new initiative in the 2005-06 budget. Even at the recent Senate estimates hearing the minister was unwilling to give a commitment on a timetable. This is demonstrated by his response to a series of questions from Senator Lundy on the matter. I quote:

quote.para: Senator LUNDYâMinister, it is five months since submissions closed on the DCITA discussion paper prepared in response to the Anderson inquiry. In February, you advised the committee that an announcement would be made before the budget.
Senator KempâI will be taking a proposal to the government in the very near future. Once that has gone through the proper governmental processes, an announcement will be made.
Senator LUNDYâGiven you made that statement in February, it implied that an announcement would be before the budget, so why has it taken so long?

Senator KempâIt is quite a complex issue. This issue was originally raised in 1990, I think. It seems to have gone through very many sports ministers. I have to say that this will happen on my watch. But there has been extensive consultation, which is appropriate because this is a very important initiative. As I said, I expect to be taking a proposal to the government in the very near future. Once that proposal has been ticked off by the government or modified or changed, an announcement will be made.
Senator LUNDYâSo you are taking a proposal to the next cabinet meeting. Is that what you mean?
Senator KempâNo, I said in the near future.
Senator LUNDYâWhy did you miss out on this budget round?
Senator KempâAs I said, it is quite a complex issue. It is one which we are very concerned to get right. Rather than meeting a timetable of a budget, it is best to get it right, to be quite frank.

speech.para: When asked by Senator Lundy how any new initiative in this area would be funded the minister responded as follows:

quote.para: Let me say on the issue of funding that if additional funding is required, I am sure we will get that approved as part of the cabinet decision.

speech.para: This is not good government; it is not even arrogance. (Extension of time granted) It is just further evidence of the governmentâs lack of serious intent when it comes to funding sport. As I have said in the House previously, perhaps we need another major doping scandal to force the government to act. I just hope this will not happen at the Commonwealth Games. If it does, this government will be to blame.

On the matter of drugs in sport, it is also interesting to note that, if the additional allocation made to the Australian Sports Drug Agency for testing associated with the Commonwealth Games is discounted from their 2005-06 allocation, there does not seem to be any new funding for the research or development of new testing techniques. I hope this is not the case, as we all know how quickly new drugs and new drug screening agents can be developed. If Australia is to remain a leader in this area we need to invest in research and the development of new screening techniques. This is certainly an area I will be pressing the minister on over the course of the next 12 months.

You can see my dilemma with this budget. Not only is there apparently no sports strategy, but there is also strong evidence of a cavalier attitude to the whole question of funding. The only conclusion I can draw from the budget papers is that, like much else in the sports portfolio, 2005-06 sports budget decisions were all made by someone other than the minister. I would love to be able to wait and hear the ministerâs response but, unfortunately, I am needed in the other chamber.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGAURAN

talk.start.para: âI am a little unfamiliar with the procedures of the Main Committee in the 12 months that have expired since I was last here, but I am rather impressed by this opportunity for members to directly put their questions before they leave the chamber and get a reply.
âThereâs another bill downstairs!

âI presume it is not meant to be a repeat of the estimates hearing. The honourable member has just read out at some length an exchange in the Senate estimates between the Minister for the Arts and Sport and his inquisitors. I can hardly add to that. I do not know what I am supposed to reveal to the Main Committee that the minister was not able to reveal in the Senate estimates. However, we will of course refer the Hansard to him for further consideration. As I listened to it, it seemed very foreign to my understanding and notions of the governmentâs tough on drugs in sport policies.

speech.para: We are funding all aspects of detection and oversight in a way that has not been done before. We had a 2004 election commitment to Building Australian Communities Through Sport, which outlined a number of measures to strengthen our drugs in sport policy by committing a further $13.5 million over the next four years for improved drug testing, advocacy, education and research initiatives. Under that policy the Australian Sports Drug Agency will receive $9.2 million. This includes $6.4 million for its drug testing program and $2.7 million for its education, communication and advocacy services. The honourable member made special mention of a lack of research funding, whereas I understand that we have set aside nearly $2 million for anti-doping research and to meet Australiaâs financial commitment to the World Anti-Doping Agency of about $350,000.

I refer to one other matter, and I was slow to rise to my feet. The honourable member asked me about Newcastle stadium or oval, which I am not personally familiar with. What I want to know is this: where are the local members? Why do we have the shadow minister for sport posing these questions when the people of Newcastle and the Hunter region should be able to depend on their Labor members? I would suggest that the Labor members pursue this matter a little bit more vigorously than by mere grandstanding in the Main Committee room. I know that the Penrith stadium received some $10 million and that Whitten Oval in Melbourneâa Labor held electorateâreceived $8 million. It is true, as the Prime Minister said, that the Commonwealth infrequentlyâeven rarelyâgets involved with capital expenditure of this kind, but as to the particular progress of anything to do with the Newcastle oval or stadium I suggest that the local members earn their keep.

talk.start.para: âI wish to pursue the issue raised by the member for Bruce with the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, who is at the table, concerning the allocation of money described in the budget paper Making Australia stronger: delivering our commitments 2005-06 on pages 41 and 42, where there is a list of grants to go to sporting and recreational organisations. That list comprises some 27 grants. The astonishing thing about it is that 16 of the 27 projects which have been approved under this list of successful grants go to just one single federal electorateâthe electorate of McEwen. That means that the rest of us in the other 149 electorates around the country got just 11 successful project grants under this particular set of grants which were made during the election period. I would like the minister to explain how any kind of grants program could involve 16 projects going to one electorate and 11 projects going to the whole of the rest of the 149 electorates around Australia and what process the government went throughâso what process the minister went throughâto produce such an astonishingly skewed outcome.

speech.para: The second thing I would like the minister to explain to us is how, of these 16 projects which went to the electorate of McEwen, 12 of them happened to be for the same amountâ$10,000. This is truly an astonishing coincidence that someone in each of the clubsâthe Broadford Bowling Club, the Gisborne Netball Club, the Kilmore Bowling Club, the Macedon Football Club, the Wallan Football Club, the Warburton cricket and football clubs, the Yarra Glen Cricket Club et ceteraâwoke up one day and said, âYou know what we really need is $10,000 from the federal government.â That is astonishing. It is not to be believed that that could have happened. What is clearly the case is that the member for McEwen went around and offered these groups $10,000 a pop. What I want to know and what the people of Australia are entitled to know is on what basis the member for McEwen was able to do this so that the government saw fit to make 12 of these 27 project grants, each of $10,000, go to these particular sporting clubs during an election period.

My further questions are: did the member for McEwen obtain authority from the sports minister before going around and offering $10,000 amounts to each of these groups, because this is clearly what occurred, and when did she obtain this authority? I cannot imagine other government members just walking around promising $10,000 to sporting clubs without having cleared it with the sports minister, so the question is: did she obtain this authority from the sports minister and clear it with the sports minister before she did it? The second thing is: were any other government members of the parliament given this same authority? As the member for Bruce noted, of the remaining 11 projects about six of them were in the electorate of Makin, so it would appear that the member for Makin was in on the deal as well. But the question is: were any other government members given the same authority to go around offering $10,000 amounts to these groups?

This is a very serious matter. It is no way to allocate taxpayersâ money. There appears to meâand I will be happy to be corrected by the ministerâto be absolutely no process of advertisement, application or assessment. If this sort of thing were going on in Papua New Guinea or the Solomons, you would have the World Bank or the IMF crying âGraftâ and giving them a lecture on governance standards. The idea was to hand out grants to groups during an election campaign with no process, no advertisement, no applications and no assessment on merit. It is astonishing that the Howard governmentâs standards have sunk so low that it apparently allows one of its members of parliament, and a minister at that, to go around handing out what have all the hallmarks of election bribes, and we are entitled to hear from the minister how it is that she had this authority to hand out these amounts and on what basis the electorate of McEwen got more than half the grants allocated around the whole of Australia.

talk.start.para: âI raise an issue relating to the ownership of radio licences in this country. A certain company has gone around Australia and, in a number of licence areas, purchased all of the available commercial radio licences. The current act says that a commercial operator can own only two licences in a broadcast market. In Townsville, for example, there are four commercial licences and the current owner owns all four licences. That particular company is required under a special dispensation given by the ABA to divest itself of two of those four licences by September this year. I understand that many people in the radio industry are looking to see what will happen. I have been approached on a number of occasions by people who are concerned that that licensee will not be required to divest itself of two of the four licences. I have sought assurances from the government that the government will stand by the current legal position and that the company will be required by the ABA to divest itself of those two licences by September. It is important that the government upholds that, because we need to have choice and competition in the radio licence market, and it is important from the listenersâ point of view that they do have that choice.

speech.para: In relation to the introduction of digital radio in this country, it is pretty well settled that we will have the Eureka system when we do move to digital, but it is not quite settled as to who will have access in the first five years, while there is a moratorium, to those digital broadcasts. All of the current commercial operators, and the ABC of course, will have access, but it is in doubt whether a class of commercial operator operating lawfully in the AM band above 1600 kilohertz will have the option of being able to transfer to digital at the same time as the mainstream commercial broadcasters. As a matter of good public policy, that broadcaster should be able to transfer at the same time as others transfer to begin digital broadcasting.

It is also interesting that we are going to face a debate as to how the digital broadcasts are actually broadcast. It would seem to me efficient if there were to be one provider of the transmission equipment who then multiplexes everybodyâs signal into the one broadcast signal so it all goes out from the one tower and that broadcasters do not have to provide all of the engineering infrastructure individually to make all of the broadcasts. I think it is very important that the government consider that, and I hope that commonsense prevails and we are able to produce an economic and efficient system.
I would just like to advise the Main Committee of complaints that I have had about Big Brother Uncut. I do not know whether any of my colleagues have had those complaintsâ

talk.start.para: âSoft-core porn!

âI would say hard-core porn, Member for Franklin. I think that it is obscene and depraved. While what is on Big Brother is what is on SBS television every night, that does not mean to say that it is right. I am of a view that that kind of television is not warranted in this country. I am not a prude but I do think that things go too far, and in this instance I think Big Brother has gone too far. Finally, Mr Acting Deputy Speakerâand I will speak about this laterâI always worry about the loss of localism in radio, as you will and as many of our colleagues will, and I hope that we continue pressuring broadcasters to continue their local content.

âI want to draw attention to a situation that has been ongoing for four years in Newcastle, in a suburb called Stockton, since the privatisation of the mail service. In that time there have been numerous representations to the various ministers. There have been community forums and I have had at least four meetings with the regional manager trying to effect change and improvements. There has been no result in spite of every effort. There have been changes in management and changes in personnel and a new contract has been drawn up and we are still being overwhelmed with complaints from the residents.

speech.para: I would also like to ask directly to Australia Post: what has been done in response to that? And why hasnât the Postal Industry Ombudsman Bill 2005 been brought forward? It has been sitting in the pile for some time. The postal ombudsman bill would perhaps be of some comfort to my constituents, who are having no satisfaction with the delivery of mail service. The problems have included things like medical bracelets being lost and 200 items of mail being dumped on the side of a road. It has been an extreme situation that has gone on far too long with no satisfactory response from the government. One would have hoped that the postal ombudsman bill would have provided some recourse to dissatisfied customers when a private contractor is employed, but that has not been the case, because in the last parliament and in this parliament the bill has sat in a pile and has not come forward. So I would like to ask: when is that legislation going to come forward? And what has been done or will be done to support the residents of Stockton with their ongoing mail problems?

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGAURAN

talk.start.para: âResponding to the member for Newcastle, I am sympathetic to any problems that the good citizens of Stockton are enduring with regard to interrupted mail services but, really, the member for Newcastle does not believe she can abandon her responsibilities and bring this into the Main Committee room. She should be out there with Australia Post like all of the rest of us. I have got dozens of licensed post offices and dozens of private contractors delivering mail. Occasionally there are problemsâsometimes they are personality problems and sometimes they are performance issuesâand I take them up with Australia Post. We resolve it on the ground to the satisfaction of our constituents. It is a bit like the Newcastle Oval issue. The member for Newcastle thinks that merely by raising these issues in the Main Committee room, dumping them at the governmentâs feet, somehow she is absolved of her responsibilities as a local member of parliament. It is a very unimpressive performance.
âMr Acting Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order on relevance. I do think it is an insult to the process, which is scrutinising this governmentâs performance, to allow such personal attacks.
(Hon. BC Scott)âThere is no point of order.

âI am happy to pursue legitimate issues. I will ensure that the memberâs comments are drawn to the attention of Australia Post, but you cannot wrap up your own failings and deficiencies in a serious representation to government. What is the local member doing with Australia Post to resolve these issues on behalf of her constituents? It may well be that we need a government senator to be involved in the issue who can properly assist the member for Newcastle in the case of Stockton and can bring the issue to a satisfactory resolution. I will ensure the minister is made aware of the issue and, to the greatest extent possible, she will bring it to the attention of Australia Post.

speech.para: Let me deal with the member for Wills and this serious matter he brings to the Main Committee roomâone that is such a calamity, that is of such pressing national importance going to the heart of good governance that he has not brought it to the attention of the House of Representatives. We have had two question times, we have had two MPIs and it has not been raised. It has not been raised because it is an absurdity. The words of the budget measures paper that the member for Wills seeks to rely on reveal the absurdity of his claims. The paper stated:

quote.para: The Government will provide $2 million in 2004-05 to contribute to sporting and recreational organisations and facilities to give effect to election commitments.

speech.para: The projects the members for Wills mentioned were in the context of an election. An election was held and now we are honouring the election promises. The amazing thing is that the member for Wills makes the greatest charges against the electorate of McEwen. I happen to have with me an extract from the Kilmore newspaper called the Free Press and the headline is âMoney thrown aroundâ. This is a report at the height of the recent election. It says: âMajor pre-election promises for projects in Wallan and Kilmore have been made in the lead up to Saturdayâs federal election. Labor candidate for McEwen, Jenny Beales, set the ball rolling last Thursday with a $1 million commitment towards the proposed multipurpose Wallan community centre. Then Jenny Macklin turns up to the Kilmore primary school, $1.6 million.â Further on in the article it says: âThere was plenty of enthusiasm on site at Wallan on Thursday as Ms Beales held centre stage on land where the multipurpose community centre will eventually be built.â It goes on and on.

Interestingly, a commitment is given by the Labor candidate to match the sporting clubs pledges made by the sitting member, Ms Fran Bailey. It is quite remarkable. Then we had Senator Jacinta Collins: âLabor child-care promisesââthat is from the Mail of 5 October. We had advertisements from Jenny Beales, the Labor candidate, about her grants and the like. Then we had the member for Wills himself. He happened to be in McEwen during the election making election promises. But from what program? There he is making promises to the honeyeatersâa lovely photo of Kelvin with the Friends of the Helmeted Honeyeater. (Extension of time granted) The headline is: âLabor commits to honeyeater fundsâ. It says, âShadow federal environment minister, Kelvin Thomasââoops, sorry, got the name wrong; it should be Thomsonââcommitted the Labor Party to providing the Friends of the Helmeted Honeyeater with $174,000 of funding during a visit to Yellingbo on 8 September.â

Come on! These were election commitments of the normal kind that the Labor Party matched. If you want an election commitmentâand the member for McMillan will know this wellâhow about $160 million? You want a doozey of an election commitment? We border the Latrobe Valley in Victoria. Out of the blue, the then shadow minister for resources, the member for Hunter, turned up with the Labor candidates for Gippsland and McMillan and promisedâwait for itânot $174,000 for the honeyeaters, not $1.6 million for the Ballan Primary School, not $500,000 to renovate a new long day care child-care centre. They promised a new power station in the Latrobe Valley for $160 million. The journalists said: âWhereâs the money coming from? What program?â The answer was: âNo, we donât know what technology. We donât know where the money will come from but weâre promising $160 million.â The people judged that in the same way they judge all election commitments. What credibility does the person making the promise bring to the pledge? Who will honour them? Are they worth while? Consequently, the reason that this matter has not had a hearing in the House of Representatives is that it is nonsensical and the Labor Party knows that.

We spent $38 million on the sporting commitments over the election period and $19 million went to the Labor Party. Over half the $38 million of sporting grants went to the Labor Party. What about Corio? The member for McMillan will know that $2 million went to the Skilled Stadium upgrade and Kardinia Park. The member for Gellibrand will know of the $8 million for the Whitten Oval. The member for Franklin is here. He will know about the $1 million that went to the Kingborough Sports Centre. The member for Barton will know about the $8 million for the upgrade of the Kogarah Oval. They are just some of the Labor grants under this programâthe same program that the member for Wills is attempting to discredit. It was a program that spent $38 million on honouring election commitments and slightly more than half of it went to Labor Party seats.

In the seat of McEwen, sporting commitments were given by the member and they were endorsed by the Labor candidate. Then you had a succession of shadow ministers coming and promising millions of dollarsâ$3.5 million was promised by shadow ministers for the Labor Party on behalf of the Labor candidate during the election. Quite frankly, I challenge the member for Wills to bring this issue to the House of Representatives where we can deal with it with a wider audience observing it.

talk.start.para: âUnfortunately, the ministerâs reply does not go to the questions which he was asked concerning the list of grants contained in the budget paper at pages 41 and 42. For the minister to talk about election promises around the country fails to deal with the issue before him, which is that 16 of the 27 grants for the whole of Australia went to a single electorate and that 12 of those grants were for amounts of $10,000. In other words, they were not applications which came up from the organisations themselves. speech.para: My questions to him are: firstly, did the member for McEwen obtain authority from the sports minister before going around and offering $10,000 amounts and, secondly, who else was given a similar authority? Were other government members given a similar authority? I repeat to the minister that this is no way to allocate taxpayersâ money. There was no advertising, no application and no assessment. The people of this country are entitled to know on what basis this money was handed out and what authority the minister had before she went around offering these amounts to those organisations.
