talk.start.para: âI wish to raise the issue of Anzac Cove and the governmentâs role in the desecration of Anzac Cove in requesting road works. We all know that way back on 18 December 2003 the Prime Minister gave an unequivocal commitment. He said then:

quote.para: ... it seems to me ... appropriate that the Anzac site at Gallipoli should represent the first nomination for inclusion on the National Heritage List. And, although itâs not on Australian territory, anyone who has visited the place will know that once you go there you feel it is as Australian as the piece of land on which your home is built.

speech.para: The next day the Prime Minister categorically stated:

quote.para: ... Iâm quite sure that the understanding that weâ

speech.para: haveâ

quote.para: Â ... with the Turkish authorities will ensure thatâ

speech.para: Anzac Cove is listed. We know that still has not occurred. Not only has that not occurred but, as a result of a request from the former Minister for Veteransâ Affairs, roadworks took place at Anzac Cove that have desecrated and changed the character of the site forever. We know from historians such as Les Carlyon that this was one of the worldâs great preserved World War I battlefields, and it has been desecrated as a result of the request by the government.

We in the opposition have been determined to get to the heart of how this desecration could occur, who funded it and what the process of accountability was. From go to whoa this has been a debacle on behalf of the government. Perhaps the final insult was the decision by the minister sitting opposite in the chamber, the Minister for Veteransâ Affairs, to approve the playing of Bee Gees songs, including Stayinâ Alive, on the morning of the 90th commemoration of the landing. The government does not seem to understand the difference between a commemoration and a celebration, and what is appropriate.

As the shadow minister for heritage, I made a number of freedom of information requests in April going to the heart of the matter, including the funding. That has been rejected by the Department of Veteransâ Affairs. I put on the record for the parliament the extraordinary decision by Helen Brinsmead, the FOI Privacy Assistant, Legal Services Group, who wrote to me and indicated the following:

quote.para: Turning to the second test, that is whether the disclosure of the documents would add to a continuing debate and the existing body of public knowledge,

In your application you infer the 90 th Anniversary of the ANZAC landings and the proposed Heritage Listing of the Anzac Area at Gallipoli are matters of âpublic controversyâ. While the details of the Anniversary commemorations have being discussed in sections of the media, it is not a continuing debate. Neither is the proposal for Heritage Listing.
On the information you have provided, it is hard to see how many of the documents would not be merely used for âcuriosity valueâ, given the lack of debate in the general media on the topics.

speech.para: But this matter was on page 1 of every newspaper in the country. It led television bulletins. It led radio bulletins. It is the subject of discussion in every Returned Services League club in the nation. Yet the government says that this is not a public issue.

It is a public issue, Minister, and we intend to pursue the answers to questions about how this debacle could have occurred and who is responsible for it. I note that some people may be forced to take the blame for this debacle, with at least one person in the department making a decision to move on or to be moved on. But the accountability stops at the top. It stops with the Prime Minister who, when we first raised questions about this in parliament, said it was âregrettableâ that the questions had even been asked. We know that the government received information from surveyors and archaeologists indicating the sensitivity of the site. (Extension of time granted) We intend to pursue this issue and this FOI. It is appropriate that this information be given to the opposition so that the government can be held accountable. You cannot hide behind rejected FOI requests.

talk.start.para: âI want to raise a couple of issues today while the Minister for Veteransâ Affairs is present. The first issue is: why has the government not honoured the service of European POWs? We have paid $25,000 to Japanese POWs or their relatives; we have paid $25,000 to the 13 Korean POWs; and we have had one former minister go to Crete to unveil a monolith there celebrating the wonderful efforts at the Battle of Crete. Many of those veterans were made POWs in Europe and underwent enormous deprivation, torture and punishment, yet none of the European POWs or their relatives have been blessed by the Commonwealth government with the $25,000 payment. This is an absolute shame. It makes a mockery of sending our troops away saying, âWeâre going to look after youâ if, when they come back, a section of them are neglected.

speech.para: My second issue is travel documentationâan absolute fiasco. I have a Cabcharge card. I imagine every member of the Public Service has a Cabcharge card. Yet veterans, many in their nineties, had to go through the humiliating experience of having to make repeat trips to their doctors because, in their haste, their doctors failed to date or sign documents, or veterans have not filled out the right little thing. So the form goes to DVA and DVA sends it back and the veteran has to make another taxi trip. We have our Cabcharge card. It is reconciled at the end of the month. Why not stop all this paperwork shuffling and reshuffling? I have spoken to DVA in Tasmania and they acknowledge that thousands of travel forms have to go back to veterans, back to the doctor and then back to DVA. For goodness sake! Give them a Cabcharge card. There is monthly reconciliation. It would solve a hell of a lot of angst being experienced by these veterans.

Another issue is the bloody-mindedness of the department. I will cite you an example. Because we have a shortage of orthopaedic and urology specialists in Tasmaniaâwe have only half a million people, not a whole stack of themâthere is no opportunity to go doctor shopping. We have a case where, because of $1,500, the Department of Veteransâ Affairs is sending a veteran to Albury where the department has found a surgeon who will charge the normal fee accepted by DVA. He has to make multiple trips to Albury for rehabilitation. His family have been sent from Hobart because the department is so bloody-minded about $1,500 and arguing about MBS Nos 48660 and 48669 in association with 48684. With a total bill in excess of $30,000, the department is arguing the toss about $1,500 and subjecting this veteran, who is going through extreme pain, to fly in a small aircraft from Melbourne to Albury, and sending his family and children over. I think this is absolutely disgraceful.

We have another example of the gold card fiasco where a veteran went to one of our private hospitals, Calvary Hospital, and needed a urologist. He was there for two hours and when the urologist was called he could not admit him because he is a gold card patient, a veteran.

These are some of the examples I would like to highlight today: the Cabcharge and travel fiasco, the European POWs and, finally, the bloody-mindedness of arguing the toss about $1,500 and subjecting veterans to further stress and anxiety after they have done the hard yards of serving the country overseas. We send them away with great fanfare, we welcome them back with great fanfare, we commemorateâas you and I did, Minister, at Gallipoliâtheir wonderful service and courage, yet some of them are still falling through the gaps.

talk.start.para: âI have a number of issues that I would like to raise with the Minister for Veteransâ Affairs. The first issue I will touch on is one that I mentioned when we considered in detail the Family and Community Services portfolio. Carers of disabled veterans who are on a supporting benefit do not receive the $1,000 carer bonus that the government allocated in the budget. The bonus is to go to carers of people on disability pensions and to carers of people on aged care pensions but, because of the different benefit, carers of disabled veterans are not entitled to that payment. I think it is a pretty shabby act that the government is not extending the $1,000 payment to these people. They are in receipt of carers allowance and will receive $600. I felt I needed to bring that to the ministerâs attention as well as bringing it to the attention of the parliamentary secretary earlier. That is something which you, as Minister for Veteransâ Affairs, need to act on. Partners of veterans look after some of the most disabled people in our community, who are really being disadvantaged by the governmentâs inaction. I trust that the minister will take that away and work on doing something to help those people.

speech.para: Another issue that I want to raise relates to the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service. Through this service counselling is provided to all sons and daughters of Vietnam vets and they are eligible to seek treatment from the service regardless of their age. It is my understanding that there is a change in the pipeline. This agreement is due to expire at the end of June 2006. I believe that it was extended for a five-year period only when Bruce Scott was the Minister for Veteransâ Affairs. It is well documented that the sons and daughters of Vietnam veterans have three times the national rate of suicide. For this reason alone, it is essential that the age limit not be reintroduced. What I am putting to you, Minister, is that, no matter what age the child of a Vietnam veteran, they suffer from significant and severe psychological problems in many cases. I believe that it is very important for the department and for you as the minister to ensure that that age limit is not reintroduced. I would like you to take that away and do something about that if you could. They are two little things to start with that I would like you to look at.

I believe there are still a number of issues that were raised in the Clarke report that have not been dealt with. I would like to see some of those outstanding issues dealt with and some of the benefits that should be coming the way of veterans actually being directed there. One area that I have been very concerned about for a long timeâand I admit that it has been driven by constituents in my electorateâis the fate of veterans of atomic testing. I notice that some work has been done, such as the review, the mortality study and a cancer incidence study, but the bottom line is that we have veterans in our communities who are dying from these diseases. On a number of occasions I have shared with the parliament the fate of one of the veterans within my electorate who was exposed to radiation at Maralinga. He is one of the few surviving members of the unit he was with. He has been through a horrendous time and has had horrendous treatments, and at the same time he has had to fight to get his entitlements. (Extension of time granted) I think it is time that the government looked at this very seriously.

I would like to draw the attention of the House to the fact that the minister has put to the House that this budget is good news for veterans. In fact, this budget delivers savings; there are cutbacks in the area of veteransâ affairs. Savings in the Veteransâ Affairs portfolio exceed new budget measures. Savings total $82.3 million and the new budget measures are only $10 million. Veterans in my electorate are pretty disappointed about that and they have asked me to direct to the minister their concerns that they are not being considered in the governmentâs policies. Rather, it has become a portfolio that deals with commemoration and monuments at the expense of delivering the services and the benefits that veterans needâpeople who have gone out there for their country and had their lives disrupted in many varied ways. Minister, I would like you to look at that.

I have raised in the House in a private memberâs motion the prospect of an Australian Victoria Cross for John Simpson Kirkpatrick. The issue has enormous support within the community. The cost to the department would be minimal. There are arguments against it, but the arguments for it far outweigh any argument against it. I have already submitted to this parliament petitions containing something like 6,000 signatures. Every schoolchild learns about John Simpson and his donkey. The donkey has received his award; it is time that Simpson received his. It is time the government got behind it rather than obstructing it. Prime Minister Holt could see the virtue of it; I think it is time that the minister and the Prime Minister joined the fight.

talk.start.para: âThe first issue I want to touch on deals with those ex-service personnel who were exposed to beryllium and the ongoing assessment of those people. I am concerned at the way the government is handling this matter. This has existed for a long time; I do not think any particular government or minister is responsible for the circumstances of the exposure as the dangers were not known at that time. However, we have known of the problem and the dangers for the last year or so and at every turn it seems as though the government is doing its best to keep the public, the parliament and the potential victims in the dark. We were told at first that this was an issue on board a couple of shipsâthe aircraft carrier Melbourne and a couple of supply ships. It then became apparent that it was more widespread and on other vessels in the Navy. It then became apparent it was also within the Air Force. We now know that the exposure to beryllium, not necessarily the illness derived from it, is widespread throughout the defence forces. At each point the government seems to have done its best to contain information rather than provide information, and that is alarming.

speech.para: In Senate estimates on 16 February this year we found out under questioning of the departmental officials that there had been eight claims for exposure to beryllium, including one death claim, and three claims under the VEA, one of which had been accepted. The officer at the Senate estimates added:

quote.para: ... this is the information we have been able to get from our system by doing some searching under beryllium and looking at notes. There may be some other cases which, because it was recorded as a disease that they had, we have not been able to find.

speech.para: In other words, the department had in its database at least eight claims, one of which was a death claim, plus three under the VEA, and acknowledged there may well be more. All the while the governmentâthe same officialsâwere doing their best to prevent the public knowing what was happening and that the information was in the database.

That of itself is concerning, but what is more concerning is that this appears to be not a matter of malaise but a matter of public policy of the government. I am delighted the Minister for Veteranâs Affairs is in the chamber. I hope that she can correct the situation, because I have before me a defence minute setting out her instructions as minister. Amongst other things, it says:

quote.para: Senior output executives will be asked at your direction not to communicate, in any form, with those potentially exposed, unless cleared to do so by the beryllium authorisation group to ensure a clear and considered flow of information.

speech.para: On one reading of that you might think that is a fair enough approach to ensure that alarm is not raised unnecessarily. At this point I am not being that generous, I have to say, partly because of what follows. It says:

quote.para: Communication with those potentially exposed will (1) provide assurances that work is progressing on obtaining factual information.

speech.para: That is fine. But it goes on, and this is the instruction from the minister:

quote.para: (2) if requestedâ

speech.para: note âif requestedâ: you do not provide the information of your own volition; you provide it only if someone is smart enough to ask you the question about something they do not know, so if they ask you the questionâ

quote.para: furnish information related to beryllium, including use, application on items and health impact, provided that this information is already in the public domain.

speech.para: In other words, only if they ask can you tell them what is already out there, what they already know. The instruction from the minister is: âYou canât actually tell them what we know as a department or a government. You can only tell them what is already on the public record.â This has all the hallmarks of an effort by the government to cover upâand why, I do not know. I am the first to accept on the facts I have available to me that this government is not responsible. No individual minister is responsible.

These diseases in veterans have been from their exposure to a compound over a long period of time. It is not as though anyone is trying to apportion guilt or blame for this. What we should be doing is trying to look after those veterans who have been exposed to a potentially life-threatening disease and to give them assurance and support. Why does the government want to go through this cover-up process? Extracting teeth is easier than getting information from the government on these matters, as veterans affected by this have commented to my office. I invite the minister to give a commitment, hopefully, about that and about a more open approach to dealing with beryllium and ensuring that potential victimsâthose who have been exposedâare readily identified and provided with the support and assistance that they should have, rather than putting this issue under some cone of silence.

The two other issues that I hope to comment on quickly are in relation to veterans of the Battle of Long Tan that I have raised these previously. (Extension of time granted) I will endeavour to be very brief. One of those issues relates to the citations and Australian awards that were given to those involved. A long series of questions have been on notice that I and other members on this side of the parliament have raised. I assume that the minister is well briefed on them. Those questions deal with the fact that Colonel Smithâs recommendations for awards for those people who were in the middle of the battle were seriously downgraded.

I remind people that this was a conflict in which about 100 Australian soldiers were ambushed by about 2,500 Vietnamese. We suffered our heaviest casualties in the Vietnam War on that day. Eighteen Australian troops and 245 Vietnamese died in that conflict. Great valour was demonstrated by the people on the battlefield. People who demonstrated that great valour on the battlefield were mentioned in dispatches. In the same gazette that mentioned those heroes in dispatches, the postal clerk in Vung Tau got mentioned in dispatches. I am quite sure the postal clerk in Vung Tau did a good job, but to tell me that he deserved the same recognition as the bravest people in that battle is an insult. The government has refused to do anything about it since these documents were released in 1996. It should do something to correct that.

The second issue in relation to those people at the Battle of Long Tan relates to a matter that I asked the minister on notice on 9 February. It concerns the wearing of the individual citations awarded to those people by the then government of the Republic of Vietnam. I invite the minister to make a clear, unequivocal and unambiguous statement about the situation with respect to those veterans who were awarded individual citations by the then government of the Republic of Vietnam as a result of the Long Tan battle. My question at the time was whether all of those people had been granted approval to wear that citation. The ministerâs cute answer was that she could not say whether all of them had, but she did not actually say whether any had.

So I invite the minister now to tell us whether or not any of those people who have been given individual citations by the then government of the Republic of Vietnam have in fact been authorised to wear the medals, in what circumstances and what are the criteria. The least this government can do now is make sure that those veterans, who are getting on in age, have the opportunity to proudly wear the citations they received for a battle which, under any circumstances, was one of the most horrific that Australians were involved in during the Vietnam War. I look forward to the ministerâs commitments to those things.

Mr Albanese interjectingâ
âOrder! The member for Grayndler has asked his questions and will hear the ministerâs answers in silence.

âHe asked who funded the road. The Turkish authorities who have responsibility for road and transport matters funded the roadworks there. The member for Grayndler then went on to the Bee Gees, having completely made a hash of his claims about battlefield desecration and so on, which were contradicted by two respected historians. With regard to the Bee Gees, I would like to explain to the House that they did not form part of the formal commemorative service, nor the prelude. The prelude was to be played at 11 oâclock. Of course, the dawn service started with a prelude and the formal service. There were thousands of people at choke points trying to enter the site. Others had been there for many hours and had set up their rucksacks, sleeping-bags and so on. People were being trodden on. The crowd control advisers employed by the Department of Veteransâ Affairs to ensure that people were safe advised that everybody had to be sitting or standing or there would beâ
Mr Albanese interjectingâ
âYou do not want to see people safe at Anzac CoveâI can see this. You would rather see young people crushed in the dark.
âCome on!
âFair go!

âMr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: I ask that the minister withdraw that. That is a serious allegation. It is an absurd position to put that somehow I support the crushing of people at Anzac Cove.
Mrs De-Anne Kelly interjectingâ
âThat is what you supported. That is what you said.
Mrs De-Anne Kelly interjectingâ
âJust withdraw it!
âOrder! I believe the minister is in order. The comment is not unparliamentary. The member for Grayndler will have an opportunity at the end of the ministerâs address to raise further concerns.

âThe Department of Veteransâ Affairs employed crowd control and expert advisers to ensure that the site was safe and that those who attended were safe. The advice of those experts was that people shouldâ
âSo Stayinâ Alive is okay?

âIf you do not want to hear the explanation, I am happy to move to the next speaker. If the member for Grayndler is not interested in his questions being answered, I will go to the member for Franklin, who is always a gentleman and listens quietly. Or do you want to hear the explanation?

speech.para: Honourable members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âWell, he is. All right, I will go to the member for Franklin, because quite plainly you are not going to give me an opportunity to respond to the questions that you said you wanted answered.
âOrder! The minister is obliged to refer to the honourable member by his electorate.

âYes, it is the member for Grayndler. Well, I will give it one last go. (Extension of time granted) The expert crowd control advice was that people should be sitting or standing so that others could enter the commemorative site. That resulted in the need, for some four to six hours in the dark and in the extreme cold, to give people some form of diversion. You cannot ask people to stand in the dark in the cold for four to six hours without some form of diversion. So it was decided, against the plan which was that there would only be the prelude and the commemorative service, that there would be some form of diversionâmusic. The music that was to hand that was a form of entertainment was by the Bee Gees. We will in future have a better choice of music but it will still be entertainment, because people cannot stand in the dark for four hours in the freezing cold and not have some form of entertainment. This was certainly on the front of every newspaper in Australia and, for the edification of the member for Grayndler, I would like to read some of the comments that those present made about the road. We had quite a range of people attending. The Chief of the Defence Force, General Cosgrove, said:

Ray Blayne, from Liverpool in Sydneyâs western suburbs, said if it helped to bring more visiting Australians of all ages to the site of the first assault and spread the news of what happened there it was a worthwhile project.
