talk.start.para: âAnd of Les Carlyon and the head of the RSL.
âYou may be interested to know that all of the veterans on the commemorative visit to Gallipoli wrote a very strong letter of support.
âOh, yeah!
âWe can certainly read it out to you.
âTell me what my RSL said.

âI do not know whether yours was there, but these were the leaders of all the ex-service organisations around Australia and they wrote a very strong letter of support. There were 11 of themâleaders of the Australian ex-service organisations in Gallipoliâwho were very supportive of the commemoration, and they would be the ones who would know because they were actually there and experienced it, unlike others who have been shooting from the sidelines back in Australia.

speech.para: The member for Franklin has raised the concern of prisoners of war who were incarcerated in Europe. The payment of $25,000 was to Japanese and Korean POWs, as he rightly said, in recognition of the unique circumstances of their incarceration. That is not to say that POWs elsewhere did not suffer. They did indeed; there is no doubt about that. Every POW deserves our greatest respect for what they went through. However, it has always been emphasised that prisoners of war of the Japanese had virtually no protection under international law. They suffered extreme cruelty in inhumane conditions. As I said, that is not to make any comparison amongst POWs. To do so would be quite unacceptable. Having just led a veterans group to Borneo, I know it is quite something to hear of the Sandakan marches, for instance. I know the member for Franklin, with his interest in military history, would be aware that of some 2,000 Australians who were transported to Sandakan only six survived. I think that is silent testimony to the absolute cruelty, deprivation and starvation that those POWs were subjected to. For that reason it was decided to make the payment available to those who had been subjected to Japanese incarceration. (Extension of time granted)

With regard to travel documentation, I will look again at the points that the member for Franklin has made. I certainly agree that we want to make things as streamlined as possible, particularly for elderly veterans. I will look again at what can be done and I will come back directly to the memberâs office, if I may.

Access for veterans in Tasmania is certainly difficult. The member for Franklin is obviously as concerned about the veteran community there as we are. Of the approximately 10,000 medical specialists around Australia there are 383 that we are aware of who will not accept the gold card, and there are some 21 in Tasmania. We recently increased fees for medical specialists; we allocated $157 million over four years. That is a 15 per cent increase on the Medicare scheduled fee for consultations and 20 per cent for procedures. Our general feedback is that most medical specialists see that as a fair outcome. However, there are special workplace issues in Tasmania that overlay that. I am not seeking in any way to blame anybody else; it is a shared responsibility. Recently in the state budget the state government announcedâcorrect me if I am wrongâ$1.2 billion in additional health funding, of which there is a significant amount to attract 25 additional specialists. They will not focus entirely on the veterans communityâobviously notâbut we believe that in the short to medium term that will improve the situation not only for veterans but also for everybody in Tasmania.

As the member for Franklin will be aware, under the Veteransâ Entitlements Act 1986 the department cannot allow veterans to pay a gap, so the medical specialist needs to accept the gold card or make some other arrangement. What we will do, though, is fly every veteranâI realise that it might not always be convenientâto expert medical care. Of the 77 patients who were flown out of Tasmania in 2004 some 67 were flown out because there was no medical specialist available in Tasmania, not because there was a lack of acceptance of the gold card. Ten of those flights certainly were as a result of a lack of acceptance of the gold card but the overwhelming majority were because of the work force situation in Tasmania.

I would like to assure the member for Franklin, who I know cares greatly about his veterans community, that we will continue to work with the state government down there. We will continue to explore every way in which we can do so but we will not allow veterans to suffer in any way. It may mean that on occasions we have to transport them by air. There are many other regional and rural centres around Australia where not only veterans have to be transported but also others have to drive considerable distances. I know that that is not necessarily a consolation but the problem is not necessarily unique to Tasmania. We will try to work with the ex-service community, the state government and medical specialists to improve the situation. I thank the member for Franklin for that question.
The member for Shortland raised the question of carers of disabled veterans receiving either the $1,000 carers payment or the $600 carers allowance.

talk.start.para: âThey received $600, not $1,000.

âThat is correct. Those are the two options. That was brought in in the previous year. Those payments are Centrelink payments, not Veteransâ Affairs payments. We in the Department of Veteransâ Affairs do not have the capacity to evaluate whether somebodyâ
âI want to have a word with the Minister for Family and Community Services to try to resolve the issue.

âThey are Centrelink payments. However, ultimately we do not have the capacity to ascertain the degree of disability and so on to be able to make those payments; they are Centrelink payments. I have said to those who have approached our office that they are entitled to apply for the carers payment through Centrelink. If they fulfilled the requirements and were successful they would automatically get the $1,000. Weâthe department and the previous ministerâhave certainly made representations but it is ultimately a Centrelink payment. I hear what the member for Shortland says.

speech.para: With respect to the issue of counselling, the agreement we arrived at after the meeting I had with partners of Vietnam veterans was that we would seek expert advice on the benefits or otherwise of having a cut-off of 36 years of age for the children of Vietnam veterans. There has been a suggestion from some experts in counselling that a cut-off of 36 years enables people to move into the mainstream and commence their own lives. We have agreed that we will follow the advice of experts on that particular issue, but I hear the member for Shortlandâs comment.

With respect to the British nuclear tests, a cancer and mortality study of Australian nuclear test participants is presently being undertaken. They are represented through a consultative forum. The study is progressing slowlyâthere is no doubt about thatâbut that is as a result of the complexities involved. Working out dosimetry levels and so on is a very lengthy process, but the government has committed to respond positively to the needs of those who are affected.

talk.start.para: âThey are dying.

âThe study in the United Kingdom by the National Radiological Protection Board of cancer incidents amongst British nuclear test participants found that they did not face a greater risk of cancer. That UK study found that a slightly increased risk of leukaemia could not be ruled out. We are obviously pursuing our own study but I want to reassure the member for Shortland that there have been studies done in other areas of large populations, and that was the outcome. But the commitment from the government, made through the Clarke report, is that when the study is completed we will respond positively to the outcome.

speech.para: In terms of the overall budget figures, the member for Shortland claims that the savings have exceeded expenditure. I did maths and I know that you cannot get a bigger amount unless expenditure is greater than savings. This is the greatest amount ever spent on veterans in Australia. The budget for this year is $10.8 billionâan increase of $278 million over last year. There is no way we could do that if the savings were greater than the expenditure. The reality is that we are spending record amounts on veterans and I am sure that the member for Shortland would be heartened by that. She would like to know that we are spending $4.6 billion on health care and $6.1 billion on compensation and income support across a whole range of portfolios. (Extension of time granted)

So there is no doubt that this budget expands the expenditure for veterans. One of the comments that the member for Shortland made was that too much was spent on monuments and not enough on veteransâ health care, income support and so on. Let me share with the member for Shortland the total amount for commemoration, which includes the maintenance of war graves around the world through the Commonwealth War Graves Commission, which I am sure members on the other side are very supportive of. The whole of that budget comes to $31 million. The overall budget is $10.8 billion. This is not a government that has an emphasis on commemoration, appropriate as it is to pay tribute to the sacrifice of our veterans in all conflicts, but it is a very small part of the $10.8 billion budget.

With regard to Simpson, like the member for Shortland I share a great regard for Simpson and believe that were it possible he should be honoured further. However, the honours and awards list for the First World War closed some 80 years ago, and there is no capacity to reopen it. Having said that, there have been many governments in the interim who have faced this very question and found it equally difficult. That is not to say that we do not have regard for Simpson; he has been honoured in many other ways. There is a statue of him outside the War Memorial. He is almost part of Australian myth now because of his courageous exploits, so he is honoured in many other aspects.

I would like to move now to the questions about beryllium by the member for Brisbane. Firstly, I reassure the member for Brisbane that serious illness from beryllium is very rare. On the Workers Compensation Dust Diseases Board of New South Wales list of those affected there is only one. So beryllium related illness is, thankfully, very rare. We have had a number of claims, and we have made no secret about those. I have given those in the House under the two acts, the Safety, Rehabilitation Compensation Act and the Veteransâ Entitlements Act. I would add that none of those five claims where beryllium was a clear factor related to Navy, but there are certainly other claims under the Safety, Rehabilitation Compensation Act that relate to the Royal Australian Navy. I would just like to correct that.

The member for Brisbane claimed that there has been a cover-up. There has been no cover-up at all about this issue, quite the reverse. We have set up a beryllium information service. The member for Brisbane said that we should not furnish information that is only in the public domain. Why wouldnât you? Are we to alarm people with unpublished studies and conjecture? The information must be accurate to give people the opportunity to make decisions about their future care if need be. The information must be accurate, not the wild accusations that we sawâand I am sure the member for Brisbane would agree with meâwhich caused great alarm. Figures such as a six per cent death rate were quoted. That was very old, historical data that was not appropriate to the current situation. So we established the beryllium information service whereby all members who rang or registered received one-on-one information as appropriate. If all they wanted was some general information about beryllium they were given that, and certainly it was information that was on the public record. If, however, they said they believed they had an illness or an injury related to their service, they were immediately directed to the Department of Veteransâ Affairs to make a claim. (Extension of time granted)

Since then 21 individuals have made claims with the Department of Veteransâ Affairs as a result of contact with the beryllium information service. So there is no cover-up. We want to give people concise, accurate information, depending on whether they are making a general inquiry or whether they believe they have a serious health impact, such that they are not, as somebody we discovered, going to a doctor to have whatever testsâand many of the physicians were not as well informed as others about a very rare and unusual illness, which is to be expected. Perhaps one could understand that. The beryllium information service was set up to give people accurate, sound information and to reduce their level of anxiety. All of those who have contacted it have been advised, if they have a health impact as a result of their Defence Force service, to make a claim with the Department of Veteransâ Affairs. Obviously, while I do not have access to those names, and nor should I, the department does and there is ongoing contact with those who have registered.

Following the Battle of Long Tan in August 1966, the South Vietnamese government indicated its intent to recognise 22 Australian veterans in the battle for gallantry and distinguished service. However, as the member highlighted, due to a strict foreign awards acceptance and wearing policy, those awards were never made. Australian governments since that timeâthat covers all governmentsâhave had difficulty resolving this issue, particularly with the government of the day having changed significantly in South Vietnam. In June 2004 the government agreed that a rare discretion in the principle of the honours and awards system could be employed to allow these medals to be worn. A list of intended awards established following the battle was also identified. The Governor-Generalâs approval was gained to allow these veterans to wear the awards offered by the South Vietnamese government at the time. I will investigate further the concerns raised by the member for Brisbane with regard to Long Tan. I know that next year is the 30th anniversary, and obviously we want to try to recognise that and satisfy concerns to the extent that we can. So I will report back to the member for Brisbane in due course.

talk.start.para: âDoes the Minister for Veteransâ Affairs have any other comments to make in respect of the other issue in relation to Long Tan, which is the Australian awards provided to those who fought in the Battle of Long Tan that were downgraded from the recommendation of the battle field commander?

âI can certainly look at it again, but in 1996 the government established an End of War List for Vietnam, as the member for Brisbane would know, to review at the highest level the awards that were subsequently downgraded in Australia. The awards in question apparently did not fit into that category. The decisions taken with regard to the appropriate level of award for Colonel Smith and his colleagues were made by the chain of command well before final recommendations reached Australia. During the preparation of the End of War List, advice was received from the Queenâs private secretary that imperial awards recommended at the time of the Vietnam War could not be used. The Order of the British Empire statutes have been amended since 1992 to exclude Australians, and this also applied to bravery and gallantry awards. Consequently, Australian awards were used, and the End of War List for Vietnam was approved by the Governor-General in June 1998, identifying 81 individuals who met the policy. There was an independent review panel established in 1999 to further review the list. Amongst other findings and recommendations, the review satisfied itself that the possibility of using imperial awards was no longer open and the End of War List for Vietnam was closed. However, I will look at the matter again.
(Mr Hatton)âThe debate on the portfolio is adjourned until a later hour in accordance with the agreed order of consideration of portfolios.

speech.para: Education, Science and Training Portfolio

quote.para: Proposed expenditure, $2,523,257,000.

talk.start.para: âI want to start in the area of vocational education and training. First of all, I would appreciate it if the minister could explain some discrepancies in figures that have been put out by his junior minister, Minister Hardgrave. In a press release on 11 May he said that the government will contribute $4.4 billion to the states and territories for vocational education and training. But most recently the same minister put out a press release on 10 Juneâjust last Fridayâsaying that the Australian governmentâs offer is worth $4.97 billion. Where did the extra $572 million come from, given that the appropriation in the bill that has gone through the House today was $4.4 billion? Can the minister explain where that $572 million discrepancy comes from? Are we actually talking about $4.4 billion? I think we probably are.

speech.para: On a related issue in the same area, Minister Nelson in his own budget press release on 10 May said that this is an annual average real increase in funding of 4.1 per cent over the quadrennium compared to 2004. However, once again, the figures detailed in the bill that went through the House this morning only represent an average annual nominal increase of 3.3 per cent over the same period. Could the minister explain how he gets an average real increase of 4.1 per cent when the numbers presented in the bill give us a nominal increase of 3.3 per cent? At this stage we would appreciate the minister clarifying those different claims.

On the related issue of the offer made to the states and territories, in the letter that Minister Nelson wrote to the state ministers it was said that 128,000 new training places would be funded as a result of the offer being made to the states and territories. Are the 71,000 training places which were offered in 2003 andâhe would rememberâsubsequently withdrawn counted in the 128,000? Can you clarify that for me as well?

I will finish up on the skills side. You would also be aware that we have some concerns about the discrepancy in the funding for the technical colleges. In the promise that was made during the election campaign the government committed to spending $289 million over the four financial years ending 2007-08. The current budget has spending of a bit over $33 million less than the government promised during the election campaign. I would appreciate it if the minister could explain how that discrepancy has arisen. It is one of the things that we as yet have not been unable to get any clarity on.

In case the advice from the department is to compare four years with the five years in the budget figures, I am comparing two lots of four years, not the five years in the budget papers. When the minister gives us an explanation for that downward revision, he might also explain how the government has determined the budget figure. Was there a per student cost arrived at in making the estimate of what the technical colleges would eventually cost? If so, what is the actual funding for each student going to be? Can the minister explain what the government has decided to pay per student for the technical colleges? Can the minister also explain whether any component of this includes the general recurrent funding under the SES system for non-government schools? Finally, in relation to the technical college costs, how much of the budget expenditure is likely or is estimated to be on capital expenditure? I would appreciate a breakdown of capital and recurrent expenditure for the technical colleges.

I have a couple of final questions on the technical colleges. We have had a number of answers about the fees able to be charged by the Australian technical colleges, but I am particularly interested in the rules that the government is going to set for technical college student fees on greenfield sitesâplaces where there is not an existing TAFE or school but where it is a whole new facility. What will be the rules that the government sets for fees at those technical colleges? A subsidiary question to that is: how will the fees for the training componentâthat is, for certificate II or IIIâthat the student will undertake be determined? Will they just pay whatever fees are charged by the partner registered training organisation? Is that what the government has agreed to do? If the minister could provide an explanation about these details on the funding of the technical colleges, it would be appreciated.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr NELSON

talk.start.para: âFirstly, in relation to the ANTA offer, the Australian National Training Authority agreement traditionally has run for a three-year period. We had to roll the agreement over because of failure by the states to sign in December 2003. We are in a situation at the moment where we have to roll it over, essentially for 12 months. The $4.4 billion figure was indeed accurate for three years, but, of course, we are required to fund for the second half of this calendar year and then for three further years. So the total offer for the period of the agreement, which will extend from 1 July 2005 to 31 December 2008, will be $4.97 billion. The $527 million includes half of one full calendar year and also $39.2 million, which is of the $42 million committed in the Welfare to Work programs specifically targeting training.

speech.para: I really do not understand the basis upon which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition puts the assertions in relation to nominal increases, but for the life of the agreement the real increases in the offer are 2.3 per cent for this year, 4.3 per cent for 2006, 4.5 per cent for 2007 and 4.7 per cent for 2008. We are of course requiring the states to match what is being offered by the Commonwealth.

talk.start.para: âI just want to get this clear, because we have in front of us the amounts that were in the legislation that we debated this morning which do not provide those sorts of percentage increases. So where else is the money coming from if it is not related to the amounts that were in the bill this morning? It also goes to the pointâand maybe the member for Hasluck got it wrongâthat yesterday in the debate he said that the extra $570 million was actually covered off by the first six months of 2005. Is that where the minister gets the extra $570 million from? Otherwise I cannot see where that money is. Has the member for Hasluck got it right? Has that money already been spent?
âYou are referring to the money for the second half of this year?
âNo, the first half.
âThe money for the first half of this year has already been spent. We leave it to the states and territories. So we have three full years and the last six months of this year.
âThat is right. That is what he said in the debate. So he got that wrong, did he?
âI have not seen what the member for Hasluck said, so I am not prepared toâ
âI am just quoting from the Hansard. He said that it âincorporated the $577 million paid in the first six months of 2005â. Is that correct?
âI apologise, it is included in the 4.9 per cent.
âSo in other words, I am correct. The 4.9 per cent actually countsâthe $577 million that has already been spent?
âOver the period of the agreement we are delivering money to the states, so of course it includes what we are delivering.
âSo it is not new.
âIt is being spent today as we speak.
âCan the minister then go on to explain how he gets the 4.1 per cent over the quadrennium? That was the point at which I interrupted.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr NELSON

talk.start.para: âAs I said, it is 2.3 per cent real for 2005, 4.2 per cent in 2006, 5.2 per cent in 2007 and 4.7 per cent 2008. It is 4.1 per cent real over the four years of the agreement. It includes additional funding of $176 million and the states and territories will be required to match the $170 million of additional funding. These additional places will be targeted as priority places such as traditional trades, areas of skill shortages, people with disabilities, Indigenous Australians and mature age people. It also includes $38.9 million over the period of the agreement for the Welfare to Work program. So in total that is for all of 2005, the first and then the second six months of course. In total it is $4.974 billion, which is a 4.1 per cent real increase compared with 2004.

âIf I can just go through the numbers that are actually in the bill, this is what is being proposed: it is $1.18 billion. We have just worked out the percentages and we cannot see how you have done them. Maybe you can provide the numbers to me later, so we do not take up the time of the committee. Perhaps you can show me exactly how you get those percentage increases, because the numbers that we have from the bill do not show those percentage increases. If you could provide the numbers that you get those percentages from it would be helpful.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr NELSON

talk.start.para: âThey are real increases from 2004.
âI know what you are saying. I just cannot get them to fit. So if you show us what you are usingâ

âYou are right, in terms of 1.189 for 2005, 1.231 for 2006, 1.269 for 2007 and 1.290 for 2008. As I said, they are respectively 2.3, 4.2, 5.2 and 4.7 per cent real increases over the 2004 base, which is 4.1 per cent over the period of the agreement.
âI canât see how that works.

âA number of the 71,000 places which were offered in 2003 have already been committed. Some of the 71,000 are rolled over to continue for this offering in the 128,200. It is worth noting that, when the states and territories refused to sign the agreement in December 2003, to ensure that not a single place was lost from the Commonwealth funding at least, we went directly to tender to the market, which is something we may well revisit if we reach an intransigent position with the states and territories.

speech.para: Funding for Australian technical colleges was announced during the election campaign in 2004 as $289.1 million over the period 2005-06 to 2007-08. Naturally, we had to make a number of assumptions around the implementation of the tech colleges and some of those have changed since that time, which impacts on the estimates provided both in the 2004-05 Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook released in December last year and subsequently in the budget documents.

Over the next five years, we are budgeting $351 million, which represents the amount agreed on with the Department of Finance and Administration. There are a number of assumptions which we make in terms of this figuring. I think it needs to be understood that we are proposing to establish 24 technical colleges and, until all of the proposals are received and carefully evaluated, it is difficult to be precise to the last dollar as to exactly how much each of themâand, indeed, collectivelyâwill cost, particularly in terms of the phasing in and their establishment. The election costing assumed all 24 colleges would commence in 2006, while the mid-year economic forecast costing provides for a more realistic staggered start. Perhaps six colleges will be established in 2006. It may well be more than that.

talk.start.para: âSorry, did you say six?

âThe costings are essentially based on the assumption that about six will be established in 2006 and then other colleges will subsequently be established in 2007 and 2008. Clearly, some will be established more quickly than others. In particular, the greenfield site colleges will take longer than those that use established schools and training facilities. The costings reflect the full complement of 300 students. We have said publicly that between 300 and 350 students will attend the colleges from their second year of operation. In the first year of intake, you will have about half that number.

speech.para: There will also be a variation to the type of college that will be established. The election costing assumed that, of the 24 established, half would be primarily government schools and half would be non-government. Until we have formally evaluated the proposals that have been received, it will not be absolutely clear what the make-up will be in terms of government versus non-government schools. There may need to be a revision to the amount of capital funding that could be required for individual colleges depending on whether the colleges operate from established facilities, as I said, or whether they are established at a greenfield site.

In the election costing, it was assumed that $10 million would be required for new colleges and $8 million for already established ones, with an expenditure spread of 50 per cent, 25 per cent, 12.5 per cent and 12.5 per cent respectively over each of the four years. In the final costing, it was assumed that $15 million would be required for new colleges and $5 million for already established colleges spread evenly over four years to reflect the build-up of students and implementation.

The change to costings will have absolutely no impact on the number of students who will be assisted by the colleges. (Extension of time granted) I would not be surprised over the next two to three years if the costings move, depending on the nature of the proposals which are finally accepted and supported by the government. I can assure the opposition that the government will deliver on these 24 technical colleges. As you can see, at this stage we have budgeted for $351 million over five years.

Where there are non-government schools involved they will attract the non-government funding, as they normally do. I will have to take on notice the question of the funding per student. You can expect that the total funding per student will be precisely that which generally would apply in any other school setting, although, given the capital intensive nature of a technical college, the capital component would be higherâbut I will take that on notice.

With respect to the fees at greenfield sites versus the fees at established sites, as I have said publicly, the fees will generally be those that would apply in a public school setting. If there is involved in the consortium a non-government schoolâwhether it be a Catholic or an independent schoolâwhich normally charges a fee, we will expect that they will charge the usual fees; certainly no more. Where a non-government school is involved and it is the principal school, we will require those who put proposals to us to let us know the precise equity measures they intend to implement to ensure that students are not precluded from attending a technical college because of financial circumstances. The fees for regional training organisations, RTOs, involved in the technical colleges, I presume, would be the same as would normally apply.
An opposition memberâSo they just continue to pay whatever they pay now?

talk.start.para: âWhatever an RTO would normally charge, we expect to be charged here. I make the commitment, again, that we will be supporting not only the capital costs but the recurrent capital costs of the technical colleges. We also expect that the states and territories will ensure that they make an appropriate contribution to the funding arrangements for the education of students for which they have primary responsibility. In other words, we are not prepared to accept that a student will move from being 88 per cent funded in a traditional government school setting to a technical college and that the state will not, in some way, continue to make a contribution to support the education of that child.

âThe issue I wish to raise with the minister comes from an email that I have received from a constituent within my electorate. He graduated from University of Newcastle and worked for 25 years in the business and law faculty there. His children attended that universityâas did I and many other members in this House, and our children as well. He raised with me his concern that one-quarter of the staff of his old faculty of business and law are to leave. He is very concerned about this and makes the point that this department has always operated at a very high level. The courses have been in great demand and he sees it as a substantial loss because 25 per cent of the academics, through no fault of their own, will lose their jobs. He is very concerned about the quality of education and the impact that this will have on people attending the university. I share his concern.

speech.para: Newcastle and the Central Coastâbecause, as you are aware, there are two campusesâis an area that has a significant population. The University of Newcastle has a reputation of being one of the finest non-metropolitan universitiesâa point that Duncan Macdonald raises in the email that he sent me. The Central Coast in particular is an area with very low participation in tertiary education and here we have a university that is being gutted. Minister, I understand that some of the issues do not relate to your actions. There is the issue of regional funding for the University of Newcastle. People in the Hunter, Central Coast and North Coast areas, which I represent, feel that you have let them down. They are the people who access that university. We would argue strongly that you really do need to revisit that matter.

The reason I am concentrating on this email is that this particular constituent, Duncan Macdonald, believes that there should be a real inquiry into the background of the situation and that you should not just allow the university to be decimated in this way. He feels that, if there are people who are responsible, they should be identified and the surrounding circumstances should be revealed publicly. He questions why you did not have your eye on the ball and why you let this happen. He believes that your role as the federal minister is to oversee universities. He calls for government assistance to overcome the problem. I support that view 100 per cent. I do not see why people living in the region I representâpeople who are already quite disadvantaged from an educational point of viewâshould be further disadvantaged. You are the Minister for Education, Science and Training, the minister for all students in all areas in Australia. If you are concerned for the future of education in this country, you will step in and deal with the issue of funding the University of Newcastle. There should be no buck passing, no smart, clever words and no sweeping issues under the carpet. There should be action. That is what we wantâaction. We want you to do something. We do not want rhetoric.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr NELSON

talk.start.para: âThe member for Shortland in this regard is a layperson, but the financial auditing and responsibility for the University of Newcastle and universities throughout the country, with the exception of the ANU and the Australian Maritime College, lie with state governments. At this very moment I am in the process of trying to drive a reform which transfers the governance, management, auditing and financial responsibility across to the tier of government which actually drives the policy and delivers 98 per cent of the public fundingâthat is, the Commonwealth government. The New South Wales government, to its credit, has already agreed to transfer its universities in that sense, not its real estate but responsibility for financial auditing, across to the Commonwealth government.

speech.para: The second point is that the editorial view of the Newcastle Herald, which I support, is that the university cannot expect that any other organisation is responsible for the circumstances in which it finds itself. John Price, one of the state Labor members, is on the council of the University of Newcastle. He and the other members of the council and the previous vice-chancellor need to takeâin my view, and in fact under the reforms that we have just managed to get through, particularly with the governance reforms in the new regimeâresponsibility for the circumstances. But there needs to be recognition that a university cannot simply get revenue from a whole variety of sources, mismanage those resources and then expect the everyday Australian taxpayer to give them more money. Further to that, at the University of Newcastle, staffing costs are 60 to 65 per cent. The national standard is 50 to 60 per cent, which has been recognised by the Vice-Chancellor, Professor Saunders, and indeed again by the Newcastle Herald in its editorials.

The other thing in terms of staffing at Newcastle University is that the university will receive $190 million from the Commonwealth governmentâthe Australian governmentâthis year. It received $168 million last year. It will receive an additional $52 million in increased Commonwealth Grants Scheme payments and increased HECS payments over the next three years, which were not universally supported here in the parliament. I might also add that when I made the decision to allocate the additional places as a product of the higher education reforms, whilst Newcastle University then had only seven per cent of all of the government supported places in the state of New South Wales, it was allocated 13 per cent of all of the new placesâ1,266 places. As you know, most of those placesâin fact, almost a thousand of themâwent to the Ourimbah campus. In terms of regional loading, one of the many features of the reforms was that we recognised that regional universities face quite different challenges from those of larger, frequently research intensive universities in suburban and built-up settings. So, using the statistical dataâcensus collection data and other thingsâwe came up with a definition, in terms of distance from a population centre and the size of that population centre, to define a regional university for the purpose of regional loading.

Wollongong University receives the smallest amount, which is 1Â½ per cent of its Commonwealth Grants Scheme funding. The reason it does is that it services 257,000 people. The Sydney statistical district for Newcastle Universityâs Callaghan campus is half a million people and for the Ourimbah campus, which is in Wyong-Gosford, it is 297,000 people. Even if Newcastle University were to get 1.25 per cent or 1.5 per cent of Commonwealth Grants Scheme funding as regional loading, it would receive an additional $1.3 million a year. It has a deficit at the moment of $25 million, $18 million of which relates to unfunded superannuation liabilities and long service leave entitlements, and it has more than another $7 million related to noncompliance with the financial management act.

I might also point out that with Newcastle University it was not until the external auditors came and had a look at the place that the university even realised that they had the financial problems that they have. Of the things that are being scrapped in terms of staffing, 148 of the subjects that are being scrapped have not even been taught for the last three years, even though there are people employed to teach them; 120 of the subjects that are being scrapped have fewer than 16 students enrolled in them. The reality is I have given them a $25 million advance which will help them and I am prepared to assist the university in any reasonable way I possibly can, but the average shop assistant, truck driver, teacher or policemanâthe average personâworking in the Hunter region needs to be reassured their money is being wisely and efficiently spent. I have got to say that, according to the vice-chancellor, it has not been. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMinister, I put it on the record that the average bus driver, truck driver, policeman, nurse et cetera in the Hunter or on the Central Coast is not happy with the way you have treated their university. We believe that the university should have regional status and we question your motives.

âI have a couple of questions on higher education. The minister would know the response of the universities to his decision not to proceed with indexation of our universities and he has been recently quoted in the media as saying that he has ruled out any further HECS increases, so I wonder if he would confirm here tonight that he will not agree to any further HECS increase above that which the parliament agreed to in 2003. On a related matter, because it also goes to the financing of universities, I wonder whether the minister will also rule out any increase in the current 35 per cent cap on Australian full fee paying undergraduate students, because obviously that is another avenue of revenue for our universities. Perhaps the minister would respond to those questions on two areas of university finance.

speech.para: Another major issue that goes to the services provided at our university campuses is, of course, the governmentâs proposal in the voluntary student unionism legislation to do away with the compulsory fee that students pay. The minister would have seen comments made by one of his colleagues, the member for Kingston, who said:

quote.para: Dr Nelson is reviewing a number of areas that have been identified by backbenchers in respect of VSUÂ ...

speech.para: I wonder whether the minister could outline the areas of concern identified by backbenchers and where he is up to in those discussions. I am sure that he will be more than happy to let us know.

I realise that time is getting away from us, but the issue of nuclear waste dumps is a very important area of public discussion at the moment. I am sure the minister will remember back in January when he said:

quote.para: It will be our determination to see that the waste will be stored at that off shore site, but to ensure that we donât fall behind the deadlines we will also be examining a Commonwealth owned remote on shore site as a fallback option, just in case for some reason the off shore site is not suitable.

speech.para: I would appreciate it if the minister would tell us what has happened since January, given we are now up to June. As I am sure he is very well aware, the Prime Minister has announced that there will be no offshore sites. Could he explain how he and the government have come to the position that there will be no offshore sites? Is it because the offshore sites would not agree to it, because the government could not find any that were suitable or because of some other reason?

On another question related to nuclear waste dumps, the minister would be aware that several states have passed legislation opposing nuclear waste dumps and the transportation of nuclear waste in their states. As I understand it, the minister is saying that the government intend to find an onshore site. How do the government intend dealing with the state legislation? Are they going to overrule state or territory legislation? I would appreciate it if the minister couldâ
A division having been called in the House of Representativesâ

interrupt.para: Sitting suspended from 6.58 pm to 7.12 pm

talk.start.para: âBefore the suspension I was asking whether the minister anticipates having to introduce legislation that will somehow override state legislation and how he intends to get around state and territory legislation if the nuclear waste dump is to be located in one of the states or territories where they have legislation that rules out a dump or transportation of nuclear waste. The final issue on nuclear waste about which I want to ask relates once again to the ministerâs 24 January press conference, when he said that he intended to make an announcement âas soon as practicableâ. He went on to say:

quote.para: We just have a couple of technical issues which we are currently seeking to resolve before I make an announcement.

speech.para: I just wonder what the technical issues are. (Extension of time granted) Given that there has not been an announcement for some time since that statement was made, I am wondering what these technical issues are and when we can expect an announcement.

I have a couple of final issues on schools and literacy vouchers. The minister would understand that we have had a bit of a debate about the rules the government has put in place requiring that a member of the government attend flagpole opening services. I wonder why the government changed the conditions. As the minister would know, originally the rules said that a federal member of parliament needed to attend the opening ceremony. But someone in the government, and the minister might like to say who, decided that the rules would be changed to a member of the government having to attend. I wonder whether the minister would consider introducing a pro forma, allowing non-government members and senators to conduct ceremonies similar to those that apply to the National Service Medal. I think that, when we are talking about national symbols such as the flag and the National Service Medal, it might assist in the process of making sure that we do not politicise the flag.

One of the practical problems that exists at the moment with the governmentâs requirement that a member of the government must attend these flag-raising ceremonies is that often schools are not reimbursed for the cost of the flagpole until a member of the government can be found. I wonder whether the minister would take this suggestion, which is being put forward in good faith, and consider it.

The final question I want to ask is on literacy vouchers. Could the minister tell us how many parents of eligible children have made contact with the brokers that have been chosen to access literacy vouchers in each state and territory? Could you let us know those figures? How many children in each state and territory have so far received any tutoring?

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr NELSON

talk.start.para: âThe government certainly has no intention of proposing to increase HECS above and beyond the changes that were introduced and agreed to late in 2003. I repeat what I have said publicly, and that is that it has been difficult enoughâit has been opposed by everybody on the other side, although I notice now it is Labor policy to accept the 25 per cent increase where it has been appliedâand we will not be moving to increase HECS.

speech.para: The full fee cap is currently that no more than 35 per cent of the students enrolled in a particular course should be full fee paying Australian students. We will not be increasing that cap. There are some issues with some universities that are running colleges of one sort or another on campuses. They are currently trying to get higher education provider status so they can get access to fee help. They are encouraging me to shift that cap, and I am refusing to do so.

On voluntary student unionism, all I can say to the opposition is: do not believe everything you read in the papers. The only concern being put to me about VSU is that it may not be implemented fully given the strident opposition of the Australian Labor Party and others to it. In fact, the government will not be entertaining any amendments to the voluntary student unionism legislation.

On nuclear waste, the governmentâs position is as I have stated and as was accurately repeated by the member for Jagajaga. The governmentâs clear preference, which we have been closely examining, is for the disposal of low-level and intermediate-level waste at an offshore facility. We have concurrently been examining possible onshore sites so that if a suitable onshore site was not able to be accessed for the disposal of this waste then we will not be behind schedule. I will make an announcement in due course when the government has made a decision about precisely what the preferred site or sites may be.

talk.start.para: âCan I just ask a question on that. You said that you are still considering offshore sites. I understood that the Prime Minister had ruled out offshore sites.

âThe problem that the member for Jagajaga has is that she believes what she reads in the newspapers. There was a newspaper report which purported a particular position on nuclear waste to the Prime Minister. As far as I am concerned, and so far as I know, there is no substance to that at all. The government will make a decision very shortly. When the government has made a decision I will be making an announcement as to precisely what that is. I can only restate that the government has ruled out Woomera in South Australia. Having said that, we have been examining appropriate offshore sites and concurrently looking at possible onshore sites just in case it is not feasible, for a variety of reasons, to use an offshore facility.

speech.para: It is the governmentâs policy, given the parochial intransigence and stubborn nature of a number of the state and territory leaders, that the states and territories be required to store their own low-level and intermediate-level waste, and Western Australia and Queensland need to be commended for doing just that. I should point out that the New South Wales government currently stores low-and intermediate-level waste at the EPA at Lidcombe, not to mention the University of Sydney and a number of other universities and hospitals. In Melbourne, waste is stored at the Peter McCallum clinic.

As to whether state legislation can be overridden or not, that issue will be addressed when I make a formal announcement on the nuclear storage issue, which, as I say, will be very soon. These issues are very complex for a whole variety of scientific, geological, legal and other reasons, but I can assure you that I look forward to the support of the opposition when the announcement is made.

With regard to literacy vouchers, at this stage I have sought the cooperation of the state and territory ministers in making sure that all parents of eligible students are aware that their students are eligible and how they might receive support. (Extension of time granted) I think we have had over 7,000 parent inquiries to our hotline, and I understand that as of last week we had almost 2,000 students actually being tutored.

talk.start.para: âAcross the whole country?

âYes, across the country. In a number of jurisdictions, the state minister has advised me that they do not even have a centralised database. At my request, they are in the process of formally advising school principals and parents that the children are eligible. So any assistance that anyone is able to give in seeing that the states and territories fully cooperate in informing parents of their eligibility will be gratefully received.

speech.para: I announced in April 2003 that I thought it would be a good idea if Australian schools flew the Australian flag. Anticipating that there would immediately be calls for the federal government to fund the flagpoles, I then instructed my department that we would make funding availableâeven though it is a state government responsibilityâfor the flagpoles. We funded the flagpoles up to $1,500 per school where there was either no flagpole or a flagpole that was not fully functioning. We funded that from the Discovering Democracy program, which seemed not an unreasonable thing to do, but contrary to what was said by some that all schools already had flagpoles and flew flagsâand I notice that seven schools in the electorate of Jagajaga have successfully applied for funding under this programâdemand has been quite significant; so much so that as of today we have almost 1,800 flagpoles that have been funded by the Australian government.

Given the demand, as we assessed it towards the end of 2004, it was obvious that it was not feasible to continue to fund the initiative from Discovering Democracy. We transferred it, quite appropriately, to the capital works program for schools. The guidelines for capital works programs for school funding state specifically that, where more than half the cost of the capital workâin this case a flagpoleâis funded by the Australian government, an Australian government representative will officiate. The schools can and do invite whomever they like to come along and speak and do whatever they like, but an Australian government representative will basically explain what the program is about, how much money has gone into it and why. I might add that the commissioning of the flagpole at the Camboon Primary School in the electorate of Cowan was officiated at by none other than the member for Perth.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)âThe question is that the proposed expenditure for the Education, Science and Training portfolio be agreed to.

speech.para: Question agreed to.
Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs Portfolio

quote.para: Proposed expenditure, $1,454,822,000.

talk.start.para: âThe governmentâs total fixation on skilled migration ensures that in this budget there is very little funding outside that area. We have a situation where $20Â million is to be devoted to the promotion of skilled migration through seminars for employers, advertising in trade journals, attending trade promotion events and developing web links. So the fixation in this budget is very much on that area. There are very few new initiatives in any other facet of the migration intake.

speech.para: With regard to refugee humanitarian entry, any increase that has occurred over the last year or so essentially balances the increase from 12,000 to 13,000 in that intake. It does not take into consideration at all the fact that the new intake is very heavily focused on Africaâon people who have been in camps for a decade plus in many cases, people with education that has been disrupted, elements of the population whose families are dispersed and broken up et cetera. So, whilst the opposition congratulates the government on taking a new thrust on the African intake within the refugee humanitarian category, the fact that an increased per capita allocation has not been made means that the settlement of these people will not be handled or done properly. Their settlement in this country is a major problem because quite obviously, as anyone who has any expertise in this area knows, this is going to be a more demanding migrant population. These are people who have basically not seen modern conveniences, have no experience of sanitation and water supplies and come from very deprived rural areas.

Returning to the skilled intakeâwhich I say is the only interest of this government: the attempt to solve very obvious skills shortagesâout of Australiaâs total intake of 137,000 next year, a monstrous 97,000 will be people coming to this country to fill shortages in the labour market. The government can talk as much as they want about high employment being the reality here. Despite the unemployment levels that are part of this debate, the crucial reality is the monstrous failure with regard to TAFE training and skills acquisition in this country.

As I said earlier, we have a new proposal here which, whenever I have mentioned it in public meetings, has elicited reactions of horror from Australians. That is the proposal that we skirt around the world to find people to come to Australia and do apprenticeships, people who will later on be able to migrate through those apprenticeships. What has happened to the country that it is no longer interested in young people, in making sure that they have the opportunity in rural and regional areas to take up apprenticeships and that they do not go to the cities because they feel there are no jobs or opportunities in regional towns? This is a total admission of defeat by the government, the fact that they have now come up with this new proposal that will bring people in from Timbuktu, Timisoara, Tehran or wherever around the world in an effort to fill these gaps. This intake of 97,000 really makes previous levels of intakes pale into insignificance. Through the nineties there was a level of 25,000 a year. By the end of next year, the government will have brought in 440,000 people under the skilled category in the period of the Howard government.

We have seen a thrust by this government to undermine conditions in the country through the entry of large numbers of temporary workers who are able to work in the Australian economy. That of course has been accompanied by no action whatsoever by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs with regard to illegal workers. We had a promise from the previous minister six years agoânot six weeks ago; six years agoâthat they would legislate to change the onus of proof against employers who hire illegals. Six years later, there has been only inaction and inactivity; nothing has occurred. In the interim, they have very much liberalised peopleâs ability to come here as temporary workers.

When we talk about bringing in so many people under the skilled category of migration, we often ignore the other part of this problem. The New Internationalist this month looked at the question of how Britain, for instance, has saved $US117Â million in training costs by recruiting Ghanaian doctors since 1998. It looked at Zambiaâs public sector retaining only 50 of the 600 physicians trained in medical schools from 1978 to 1999. It talked about QueenslandâQueensland is very topical, of course, with regard to medical labourâwhere 40 per cent of the medical work force was trained abroad. (Extension of time granted) I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

item.para: Telstra has advised that the consultation and notification to Council, residents, and other concerned parties was conducted in accordance with Australian Communications Industry Forum (ACIF) Industry Code for the Deployment of Mobile Phone Networks (Industry Code).

Telstra has further advised that on 27 October 2004, it notified the Leichhardt Council of its intention to install antennas on an existing floodlight pole within Leichhardt Oval, which included a proposed consultation plan.

(2)Â Â Telstra has advised that the reason for deciding to install antennae on an existing floodlight pole within Leichhardt Oval was to provide GSM and CDMA coverage to the surrounding areas. Telstra advised that this area has poor reception and has for some time been the basis of complaints by customers of poor quality mobile service.

Telstra further advised that after looking at alternative options, the Leichhardt Oval was considered to be the most appropriate site as it would provide the least visual impact on the surrounding community. Additionally, it was noted that Optus had already constructed a similar installation on one of the other floodlight poles at the Oval.
No opposition or objection to the proposal was received by Telstra until it commenced its notification and consultation process.

(3)Â Â Telstra has advised that alternative sites have been considered, but the Oval area proved the only feasible option. Telstra further advised that the surrounding area is comprised almost completely of residential dwellings, and available locations/space for a mobile telecommunications facility are limited. Telstra further advised that a consultation and notification process with the Council, residents and other concerned parties was conducted in accordance with the Australian Communications Industry Forum (ACIF) Industry Code for the Deployment of Mobile Phone Networks (the Industry Code). talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Science and Training, in writing, on 10 March 2005:

quote.para: For (a) Australia, and (b) the electoral division of Prospect, what was the (i) total outstanding Student Financial Supplement Scheme loan balance, and (ii) number of outstanding loans at the conclusion of the scheme.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr Nelson

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: The total amount of outstanding Student Financial Supplement Scheme loan balance and the number of outstanding loans cannot be reliably ascertained as two separate sets of dissimilar data are maintained by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) and Centrelink.

Under the Student Financial Supplement Scheme, a student took out a loan with the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. In the first five years of the loan, repayments are voluntary. In the fifth year from when each loan was taken out that loan is referred to the ATO. Once the studentâs income reaches the threshold ($37,667 in 2004-05 prices) the student is required to make repayments of the loan through the taxation system. The ATO holds data relating to Student Financial Supplement Scheme debts incurred in the years 1993 to 1999. Repayment of these loans is income-contingent. Centrelink holds the data relating to loans incurred in the years 1999 to 2003. Repayments for these loans are still voluntary. This data will be progressively handed over to the ATO until 2008 when the last of the loans become due for income-contingent collection through the taxation system.

Trying to compare the different data distorts the actual amounts owing as the records refer to different data sets. ATO and Centrelink maintain separate and dissimilar records. Under the Student Financial Supplement Scheme a student had to make a separate loan application and sign a separate contract for each calendar year in which they took out a loan. Centrelink treats each loan as a separate debt with some students having multiple debts. By contrast, the ATO consolidates each separate debt amount received from Centrelink into one debt amount for collection purposes.

The ATO estimates that total outstanding debt as at 11 May 2005 (the date of the Parliamentary question) in respect of Student Financial Supplement Scheme loans held by persons with a residential address in Australia is $1,338,224,166; and the number of clients with outstanding debts was 157,572.

Centrelink estimates that the total outstanding debt as at 31 December 2003 (the most recently available figures), in respect of loans held by persons with a residential address in Australia, was $943,494,316; and the number of outstanding loans as at 31 December 2003 was 223,096. The number of loans does not equate to the number of clients.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The amount of outstanding Student Financial Supplement Scheme loan balance and the number of outstanding loans in the electorate of Prospect cannot be ascertained.
The ATO advises that their data is not able to be sorted by electoral division.

Centrelink is able to sort the data it manages on the loans by postcode. The information for the electorate of Prospect is indicative only, as some postcodes in the electorate of Prospect cross electoral boundaries.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, in writing, on 10 May 2005:

item.para: Can he provide details on the Australian Governmentâs contribution to and implementation of the United Nationsâ Millennium Development Goals.
Has the Government considered the British Government report by the Commission for Africa Our Common Interest; if so, what is the Governmentâs response.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The Australian Government contributes to the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) through a range of policies and actions focused on promoting the conditions necessary for economic development and poverty alleviation. Australia has increased its Overseas Development Assistance (ODA) in real terms by 37 per cent since 1997, and will provide an estimated $2.491 billion in ODA in 2005-06, an increase of $358 million on the 2004-05 budget. The government provides ODA to invest in health, HIV/AIDS prevention, education, and rural integration and development in low-income countries. The government has doubled its HIV/AIDS commitment to $600 million by 2010, including a new $50 million contribution to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria. The governmentâs commitment to global efforts to manage the prevention and treatment of HIV/AIDS directly addresses one of the MDGs.

The government has invested in many of the MDGs in the 2005-06 Aid Budget. In 2005-06 Australia will spend more than $1 billion on activities related to governance, including law and justice, economic reform, civil society and human rights. Direct expenditure on health and education will increase by $81 million compared to the 2004-05 budget, to a total of over $600 million, including basic health and education in Indonesia and the Philippines. Expenditure on water and sanitation will total $152 million, where Australia is leading international efforts in promoting water quality. The Aid Budget also provided for $305 million in programs related to the environment, including support for the Global Environment Facility and Montreal Protocol Multilateral Fund.

The position of the Australian Government is that ODA alone is not sufficient to meet the MDGs. The government is committed to ensuring that its contribution to and implementation of the MDGs is aligned with broader efforts to support global economic growth through the Cairns Group in the World Trade Organisation (WTO) Doha Development Agenda round, the Heavily Indebted Poor Countries (HIPC) Initiative, and the Paris Club. Â Â Â Â

In its approach to the MDGs, Australia has emphasised the importance of balancing calls for ODA increases against the need for developing countries to pursue good governance, end corruption and harness other sources of finance to generate the growth needed to reduce poverty. Australia will produce a report in the lead up to the UN Summit, outlining how a partnership approach focused on improvements in economic policy, good governance, trade liberalisation, debt, and aid effectiveness will fast-track progress towards achieving the MDGs.

The government has considered the report of the British Governmentâs Commission for Africa, Our Common Interest. The Australian Government supports the reportâs focus on good governance and accountability, its emphasis on the importance of stability and security to underpin effective development, and the need to abolish trade distorting subsidies in agriculture.

In response to the reportâs recommendation for an additional $US25 billion per year in aid to Africa by 2010, the Australian Government emphasises that any such increase would need to be accompanied by a reduction of barriers to trade and good governance measures.

While the governmentâs first priority remains the provision of targeted development assistance to the Asia â Pacific region, the government contributes funding and supports programs to assist Africa. The government will increase aid to Africa from the 2004-05 budget estimate of $67.5 million to $77 million in 2005-06.

The December 2004 review conducted by the Development Assistance Committee of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) noted its support for Australian Aid to Africa and acknowledged Australiaâs focus on aid to its immediate region.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, in writing, on 10 May 2005:

item.para: Is the Minister aware that the decision of January 2005 to amend anti-dumping measures has not resulted in the expected price increases for Korean copper tube in the Australian market.

Is the Minister aware of the specific nature of the complaints raised by Kembla Tube and Fittings in correspondence dated 14 March 2005 and at a meeting with Australian Customs Service (ACS) officers on 1 March 2005.
What is the reason for the lack of response by the ACS to the issues raised by Kembla Tube and Fittings.

What investigations have taken place to determine how the Global Metal Group (GMG), an importer of copper tube from Korean manufacturer Dae Jin, is able to sell imported tube at prices lower than those predating the January 2005 decision.
Has the ACS visited GMG to conduct a thorough investigation; if not, why not.
Has a sales route exercise been undertaken; if not, (a) why not and (b) when will one be undertaken.
Is the lack of action by the Dumping Liaison Unit of ACS a result of inadequate resources and staff.
What action is being undertaken to ensure compliance with the amended anti-dumping measures applying to copper tube exported by Korea.

What are the âerrorsâ referred to in the Ministerâs letter to Kembla Products dated 13 April 2005 which states that âCustoms has identified some errors as a result of its monitoring activity and is in the process of conducting further inquiresâ and are penalties to be imposed to ensure âerrorsâ do not recur.
Will the Minister agree to the request by Kembla Tube and Fittings for a full investigation into the reports of copper tube sold at a loss by Global Metal Group; if not, why not.

Is the Minister aware that jobs at Port Kembla could be lost if importers of copper tube from Korea are able to flout the revised anti-dumping measures announced on 12 January 2005; if so, what action does the Minister propose to ensure this does not occur.
What action will the Minister take to address the problems which are causing material injury to the operations and employment at Kembla Tube and Fittings.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.para: I am aware of Kembla Tube and Fittingsâ assertion that the decision of January 2005 to amend anti-dumping measures has not resulted in the expected price increases for copper tube from the Republic of Korea (Korea) in the Australian market.

Yes, I am aware of the specific nature of the complaints raised by Kembla Tube and Fittings in correspondence dated 14 March 2005 and at a meeting with Australian Customs Service (Customs) officers on 1 March 2005.

Customs has responded to the issues raised by Kembla Tube and Fittings. Customs met with Kembla Tube and Fittings on 1 March 2005 and also responded by letter on 22 March 2005 stating that certain inquiries were being undertaken. As Customs is bound by the constraints of section 16 of the Customs Administration Act 1975, Customs has not been able to provide Kembla Tube and Fittings with the detail of the inquiries undertaken.
Since January 2005 investigations have been undertaken or commenced into imports of copper tube from Korea which have involved or will involve visits to importers and exporters. Additionally:

- Certain anti-dumping measures against copper tube from Korea are due to expire in May 2006. The expiration of the measures was advertised on 26 April 2005 and called for applications to be made for the continuation of the measures. A continuation inquiry would allow for a review of imports of copper tube from Korea, including re-assessing injury to the Australian industry;
- The monitoring of imports has continued over this period to ensure compliance with the anti-dumping measures in place for the imports from Korea.

These inquiries will seek to establish that the sales of the copper tube are at arms length as required by law. It is a commercial decision for importers to choose to sell the goods at prices lower than those pre-dating January 2005.

A thorough investigation of imports of copper tube from Korea was undertaken in the second half of 2004 as part of the Review Inquiry that established the new levels of measures in January 2005. Further investigations will be undertaken as part of current inquiries and as part of the anticipated continuation inquiry.

A sales route exercise is usually undertaken in order to establish that the transactions between importers and exporters are at arms-length. As noted at Question (4), previous inquiries have been and future inquiries will be made to establish that the transactions are at arms length.
As outlined above, Customs has been active in pursuing the issues involved in copper tube measures as allowed by law.
Customs is continuing to monitor imports of copper tube to ensure that there is compliance with the amended anti-dumping measures applying to copper tube exported from Korea.

Errors were found in some entries for home consumption of copper tube imported from Korea. Most of these were minor in nature, for example: use of incorrect classification and statistical codes. Corrective action has been taken. For the remainder, where underpayment of interim dumping duty was involved, Customs is in the process of undertaking recovery action. Penalties are being considered as part of this action.

A full investigation was undertaken into imports of copper tube from Korea during the review inquiry that established the revised level of measures. Another full investigation will be undertaken during the anticipated continuation inquiry.

I am aware of the claims made by Kembla Tube and Fittings. It has not been ascertained if the alleged threat of job losses would be due entirely, or even partly, to anti-dumping factors. Customs is currently undertaking (and anticipates undertaking) further inquiries into imports of copper tube from Korea as noted at Question (4). I will wait on the outcome of these inquiries before deciding if any further action is warranted.

If during the course of the inquiries, material injury to is found to be continuing, or is likely to recur, to Kembla Tube and Fittings, I may decide to continue the measures for a further five years.
